speaker: Kafka Tamura
text: Kafka on the Shore by Haruki Murakami The Boy Named Crow "So you're all set for money, then?

speaker: None
text: the boy named Crow asks in his typical sluggish voice.

speaker: None
text: The kind of voice like when you've just woken up and your mouth still feels heavy and dull.

speaker: None
text: But he's just pretending.

speaker: None
text: He's totally awake.

speaker: None
text: As always.

speaker: None
text: I nod.

speaker: None
text: How much?

speaker: None
text: I review the numbers in my head.

speaker: None
text: Close to thirty-five hundred in cash, plus some money I can get from an ATM.

speaker: None
text: I know it's not a lot, but it should be enough.

speaker: None
text: For the time being.

speaker: None
text: Not bad," the boy named Crow says.

speaker: None
text: For the time being.

speaker: None
text: I give him another nod.

speaker: None
text: I'm guessing this isn't Christmas money from Santa Claus.

speaker: None
text: Yeah, you're right," I reply.

speaker: None
text: Crow smirks and looks around.

speaker: None
text: I imagine you've started by rifling drawers, am I right?

speaker: None
text: I don't say anything.

speaker: None
text: He knows whose money we're talking about, so there's no need for any long-winded interrogations.

speaker: None
text: He's just giving me a hard time.

speaker: None
text: No matter, Crow says.

speaker: None
text: You really need this money and you're going to get it-- beg, borrow, or steal.

speaker: None
text: It's your father's money, so who cares, right?

speaker: None
text: Get your hands on that much and you should be able to make it.

speaker: None
text: For the time being.

speaker: None
text: But what's the plan after it's all gone?

speaker: None
text: Money isn't like mushrooms in a forest--it doesn't just pop up on its own, you know.

speaker: None
text: You'll need to eat, a place to sleep.

speaker: None
text: One day you're going to run out.

speaker: None
text: I'll think about that when the time comes," I say.

speaker: None
text: When the time comes, Crow repeats, as if weighing these words in his hand.

speaker: None
text: I nod.

speaker: None
text: Like by getting a job or something?

speaker: None
text: Maybe," I say.

speaker: None
text: Crow shakes his head.

speaker: None
text: You know, you've got a lot to learn about the world.

speaker: None
text: Listen--what kind of job could a fifteen-year-old kid get in some far-off place he's never been to before?

speaker: None
text: You haven't even finished junior high.

speaker: None
text: Who do you think's going to hire you?

speaker: None
text: I blush a little.

speaker: None
text: It doesn't take much to make me blush.

speaker: None
text: Forget it, he says.

speaker: None
text: You're just getting started and I shouldn't lay all this depressing stuff on you.

speaker: None
text: You've already decided what you're going to do, and all that's left is to set the wheels in motion.

speaker: None
text: I mean, it's your life.

speaker: None
text: Basically you gotta go with what you think is right.

speaker: None
text: That's right.

speaker: None
text: When all is said and done, it is my life.

speaker: None
text: I'll tell you one thing, though.

speaker: None
text: You're going to have to get a lot tougher if you want to make it.

speaker: None
text: I'm trying my best," I say.

speaker: None
text: I'm sure you are, Crow says.

speaker: None
text: These last few years you've gotten a whole lot stronger.

speaker: None
text: I've got to hand it to you.

speaker: None
text: I nod again.

speaker: None
text: But let's face it--you're only fifteen, Crow goes on.

speaker: None
text: Your life's just begun and there's a ton of things out in the world you've never laid eyes on.

speaker: None
text: Things you never could imagine.

speaker: None
text: As always, we're sitting beside each other on the old sofa in my father's study.

speaker: None
text: Crow loves the study and all the little objects scattered around there.

speaker: None
text: Now he's toying with a bee-shaped glass paperweight.

speaker: None
text: If my father was at home, you can bet Crow would never go anywhere near it.

speaker: None
text: But I have to get out of here, I tell him.

speaker: None
text: No two ways around it.

speaker: None
text: Yeah, I guess you're right.

speaker: None
text: He places the paperweight back on the table and links his hands behind his head.

speaker: None
text: Not that running away's going to solve everything.

speaker: None
text: I don't want to rain on your parade or anything, but I wouldn't count on escaping this place if I were you.

speaker: None
text: No matter how far you run.

speaker: None
text: Distance might not solve anything.

speaker: None
text: The boy named Crow lets out a sigh, then rests a fingertip on each of his closed eyelids and speaks to me from the darkness within.

speaker: None
text: How about we play our game?

speaker: None
text: he says.

speaker: None
text: All right, I say.

speaker: None
text: I close my eyes and quietly take a deep breath.

speaker: None
text: Okay, picture a terrible sandstorm, he says.

speaker: None
text: Get everything else out of your head.

speaker: None
text: I do what he says, get everything else out of my head.

speaker: None
text: I forget who I am, even.

speaker: None
text: I'm a total blank.

speaker: None
text: Then things start to surface.

speaker: None
text: Things that--as we sit here on the old leather sofa in my father's study--both of us can see.

speaker: None
text: Sometimes fate is like a small sandstorm that keeps changing directions, Crow says.

speaker: None
text: Sometimes fate is like a small sandstorm that keeps changing directions.

speaker: None
text: You change direction but the sandstorm chases you.

speaker: None
text: You turn again, but the storm adjusts.

speaker: None
text: Over and over you play this out, like some ominous dance with death just before dawn.

speaker: None
text: Why?

speaker: None
text: Because this storm isn't something that blew in from far away, something that has nothing to do with you.

speaker: None
text: This storm is you.

speaker: None
text: Something inside of you.

speaker: None
text: So all you can do is give in to it, step right inside the storm, closing your eyes and plugging up your ears so the sand doesn't get in, and walk through it, step by step.

speaker: None
text: There's no sun there, no moon, no direction, no sense of time.

speaker: None
text: Just fine white sand swirling up into the sky like pulverized bones.

speaker: None
text: That's the kind of sandstorm you need to imagine.

speaker: None
text: And that's exactly what I do.

speaker: None
text: I imagine a white funnel stretching up vertically like a thick rope.

speaker: None
text: My eyes are closed tight, hands cupped over my ears, so those fine grains of sand can't blow inside me.

speaker: None
text: The sandstorm draws steadily closer.

speaker: None
text: I can feel the air pressing on my skin.

speaker: None
text: It really is going to swallow me up.

speaker: None
text: The boy called Crow softly rests a hand on my shoulder, and with that the storm vanishes.

speaker: None
text: From now on--no matter what--you've got to be the world's toughest fifteenyear- old.

speaker: None
text: That's the only way you're going to survive.

speaker: None
text: And in order to do that, you've got to figure out what it means to be tough.

speaker: None
text: You following me?

speaker: None
text: I keep my eyes closed and don't reply.

speaker: None
text: I just want to sink off into sleep like this, his hand on my shoulder.

speaker: None
text: I hear the faint flutter of wings.

speaker: None
text: You're going to be the world's toughest fifteen-year-old, Crow whispers as I try to fall asleep.

speaker: None
text: Like he was carving the words in a deep blue tattoo on my heart.

speaker: None
text: And you really will have to make it through that violent, metaphysical, symbolic storm.

speaker: None
text: No matter how metaphysical or symbolic it might be, make no mistake about it: it will cut through flesh like a thousand razor blades.

speaker: None
text: People will bleed there, and you will bleed too.

speaker: None
text: Hot, red blood.

speaker: None
text: You'll catch that blood in your hands, your own blood and the blood of others.

speaker: None
text: And once the storm is over you won't remember how you made it through, how you managed to survive.

speaker: None
text: You won't even be sure, in fact, whether the storm is really over.

speaker: None
text: But one thing is certain.

speaker: None
text: When you come out of the storm you won't be the same person who walked in.

speaker: None
text: That's what this storm's all about.

speaker: None
text: On my fifteenth birthday I'll run away from home, journey to a far-off town, and live in a corner of a small library.

speaker: None
text: It'd take a week to go into the whole thing, all the details.

speaker: None
text: So I'll just give the main point.

speaker: None
text: On my fifteenth birthday I'll run away from home, journey to a far-off town, and live in a corner of a small library.

speaker: None
text: It sounds a little like a fairy tale.

speaker: None
text: But it's no fairy tale, believe me.

speaker: None
text: No matter what sort of spin you put on it.

speaker: None
text: 1 Cash isn't the only thing I take from my father's study when I leave home.

speaker: None
text: I take a small, old gold lighter--I like the design and feel of it--and a folding knife with a really sharp blade.

speaker: None
text: Made to skin deer, it has a five-inch blade and a nice heft.

speaker: None
text: Probably something he bought on one of his trips abroad.

speaker: None
text: I also take a sturdy, bright pocket flashlight out of a drawer.

speaker: None
text: Plus sky blue Revo sunglasses to disguise my age.

speaker: None
text: I think about taking my father's favorite Sea-Dweller Oyster Rolex.

speaker: None
text: It's a beautiful watch, but something flashy will only attract attention.

speaker: None
text: My cheap plastic Casio watch with an alarm and stopwatch will do just fine, and might actually be more useful.

speaker: None
text: Reluctantly, I return the Rolex to its drawer.

speaker: None
text: From the back of another drawer I take out a photo of me and my older sister when we were little, the two of us on a beach somewhere with grins plastered across our faces.

speaker: None
text: My sister's looking off to the side so half her face is in shadow and her smile is neatly cut in half.

speaker: None
text: It's like one of those Greek tragedy masks in a textbook that's half one idea and half the opposite.

speaker: None
text: Light and dark.

speaker: None
text: Hope and despair.

speaker: None
text: Laughter and sadness.

speaker: None
text: Trust and loneliness.

speaker: None
text: For my part I'm staring straight ahead, undaunted, at the camera.

speaker: None
text: Nobody else is there at the beach.

speaker: None
text: My sister and I have on swimsuits--hers a red floralprint one-piece, mine some baggy old blue trunks.

speaker: None
text: I'm holding a plastic stick in my hand.

speaker: None
text: White foam is washing over our feet.

speaker: None
text: Who took this, and where and when, I have no clue.

speaker: None
text: And how could I have looked so happy?

speaker: None
text: And why did my father keep just that one photo?

speaker: None
text: The whole thing is a total mystery.

speaker: None
text: I must have been three, my sister nine.

speaker: None
text: Did we ever really get along that well?

speaker: None
text: I have no memory of ever going to the beach with my family.

speaker: None
text: No memory of going anywhere with them.

speaker: None
text: No matter, though--there is no way I'm going to leave that photo with my father, so I put it in my wallet.

speaker: None
text: I don't have any photos of my mother.

speaker: None
text: My father threw them all away.

speaker: None
text: After giving it some thought I decide to take the cell phone with me.

speaker: None
text: Once he finds out I've taken it, my father will probably get the phone company to cut off service.

speaker: None
text: Still, I toss it into my backpack, along with the adapter.

speaker: None
text: Doesn't add much weight, so why not.

speaker: None
text: When it doesn't work anymore I'll just chuck it.

speaker: None
text: Just the bare necessities, that's all I need.

speaker: None
text: Choosing which clothes to take is the hardest thing.

speaker: None
text: I'll need a couple sweaters and pairs of underwear.

speaker: None
text: But what about shirts and trousers?

speaker: None
text: Gloves, mufflers, shorts, a coat?

speaker: None
text: There's no end to it.

speaker: None
text: One thing I do know, though.

speaker: None
text: I don't want to wander around some strange place with a huge backpack that screams out, Hey, everybody, check out the runaway!

speaker: None
text: Do that and someone is sure to sit up and take notice.

speaker: None
text: Next thing you know the police will haul me in and I'll be sent straight home.

speaker: None
text: If I don't wind up in some gang first.

speaker: None
text: Any place cold is definitely out, I decide.

speaker: None
text: Easy enough, just choose the opposite-- a warm place.

speaker: None
text: Then I can leave the coat and gloves behind, and get by with half the clothes.

speaker: None
text: I pick out wash-and-wear-type things, the lightest ones I have, fold them neatly, and stuff them in my backpack.

speaker: None
text: I also pack a three-season sleeping bag, the kind that rolls up nice and tight, toilet stuff, a rain poncho, notebook and pen, a Walkman and ten discs--got to have my music--along with a spare rechargeable battery.

speaker: None
text: That's about it.

speaker: None
text: No need for any cooking gear, which is too heavy and takes up too much room, since I can buy food at the local convenience store.

speaker: None
text: It takes a while but I'm able to subtract a lot of things from my list.

speaker: None
text: I add things, cross them off, then add a whole other bunch and cross them off, too.

speaker: None
text: My fifteenth birthday is the ideal time to run away from home.

speaker: None
text: Any earlier and it'd be too soon.

speaker: None
text: Any later and I would have missed my chance.

speaker: None
text: During my first two years in junior high, I'd worked out, training myself for this day.

speaker: None
text: I started practicing judo in the first couple years of grade school, and still went sometimes in junior high.

speaker: None
text: But I didn't join any school teams.

speaker: None
text: Whenever I had the time I'd jog around the school grounds, swim, or go to the local gym.

speaker: None
text: The young trainers there gave me free lessons, showing me the best kind of stretching exercises and how to use the fitness machines to bulk up.

speaker: None
text: They taught me which muscles you use every day and which ones can only be built up with machines, even the correct way to do a bench press.

speaker: None
text: I'm pretty tall to begin with, and with all this exercise I've developed pretty broad shoulders and pecs.

speaker: None
text: Most strangers would take me for seventeen.

speaker: None
text: If I ran away looking my actual age, you can imagine all the problems that would cause.

speaker: None
text: Other than the trainers at the gym and the housekeeper who comes to our house every other day--and of course the bare minimum required to get by at school--I barely talk to anyone.

speaker: None
text: For a long time my father and I have avoided seeing each other.

speaker: None
text: We live under the same roof, but our schedules are totally different.

speaker: None
text: He spends most of his time in his studio, far away, and I do my best to avoid him.

speaker: None
text: The school I'm going to is a private junior high for kids who are upper-class, or at least rich.

speaker: None
text: It's the kind of school where, unless you really blow it, you're automatically promoted to the high school on the same campus.

speaker: None
text: All the students dress neatly, have nice straight teeth, and are boring as hell.

speaker: None
text: Naturally I have zero friends.

speaker: None
text: I've built a wall around me, never letting anybody inside and trying not to venture outside myself.

speaker: None
text: Who could like somebody like that?

speaker: None
text: They all keep an eye on me, from a distance.

speaker: None
text: They might hate me, or even be afraid of me, but I'm just glad they didn't bother me.

speaker: None
text: Because I had tons of things to take care of, including spending a lot of my free time devouring books in the school library.

speaker: None
text: I always paid close attention to what was said in class, though.

speaker: None
text: Just like the boy named Crow suggested.

speaker: None
text: The facts and techniques or whatever they teach you in class isn't going to be very useful in the real world, that's for sure.

speaker: None
text: Let's face it, teachers are basically a bunch of morons.

speaker: None
text: But you've got to remember this: you're running away from home.

speaker: None
text: You probably won't have any chance to go to school anymore, so like it or not you'd better absorb whatever you can while you've got the chance.

speaker: None
text: Become like a sheet of blotting paper and soak it all in.

speaker: None
text: Later on you can figure out what to keep and what to unload.

speaker: None
text: I did what he said, like I almost always do.

speaker: None
text: My brain like a sponge, I focused on every word said in class and let it all sink in, figured out what it meant, and committed everything to memory.

speaker: None
text: Thanks to this, I barely had to study outside of class, but always came out near the top on exams.

speaker: None
text: My muscles were getting hard as steel, even as I grew more withdrawn and quiet.

speaker: None
text: I tried hard to keep my emotions from showing so that no one--classmates and teachers alike--had a clue what I was thinking.

speaker: None
text: Soon I'd be launched into the rough adult world, and I knew I'd have to be tougher than anybody if I wanted to survive.

speaker: None
text: My eyes in the mirror are cold as a lizard's, my expression fixed and unreadable.

speaker: None
text: I can't remember the last time I laughed or even showed a hint of a smile to other people.

speaker: None
text: Even to myself.

speaker: None
text: I'm not trying to imply I can keep up this silent, isolated facade all the time.

speaker: None
text: Sometimes the wall I've erected around me comes crumbling down.

speaker: None
text: It doesn't happen very often, but sometimes, before I even realize what's going on, there I am--naked and defenseless and totally confused.

speaker: None
text: At times like that I always feel an omen calling out to me, like a dark, omnipresent pool of water.

speaker: None
text: A dark, omnipresent pool of water.

speaker: None
text: It was probably always there, hidden away somewhere.

speaker: None
text: But when the time comes it silently rushes out, chilling every cell in your body.

speaker: None
text: You drown in that cruel flood, gasping for breath.

speaker: None
text: You cling to a vent near the ceiling, struggling, but the air you manage to breathe is dry and burns your throat.

speaker: None
text: Water and thirst, cold and heat--these supposedly opposite elements combine to assault you.

speaker: None
text: The world is a huge space, but the space that will take you in--and it doesn't have to be very big--is nowhere to be found.

speaker: None
text: You seek a voice, but what do you get?

speaker: None
text: Silence.

speaker: None
text: You look for silence, but guess what?

speaker: None
text: All you hear over and over and over is the voice of this omen.

speaker: None
text: And sometimes this prophetic voice pushes a secret switch hidden deep inside your brain.

speaker: None
text: Your heart is like a great river after a long spell of rain, spilling over its banks.

speaker: None
text: All signposts that once stood on the ground are gone, inundated and carried away by that rush of water.

speaker: None
text: And still the rain beats down on the surface of the river.

speaker: None
text: Every time you see a flood like that on the news you tell yourself: That's it.

speaker: None
text: That's my heart.

speaker: None
text: Before running away from home I wash my hands and face, trim my nails, swab out my ears, and brush my teeth.

speaker: None
text: I take my time, making sure my whole body's well scrubbed.

speaker: None
text: Being really clean is sometimes the most important thing there is.

speaker: None
text: I gaze carefully at my face in the mirror.

speaker: None
text: Genes I'd gotten from my father and mother--not that I have any recollection of what she looked like--created this face.

speaker: None
text: I can do my best to not let any emotions show, keep my eyes from revealing anything, bulk up my muscles, but there's not much I can do about my looks.

speaker: None
text: I'm stuck with my father's long, thick eyebrows and the deep lines between them.

speaker: None
text: I could probably kill him if I wanted to--I'm sure strong enough--and I can erase my mother from my memory.

speaker: None
text: But there's no way to erase the DNA they passed down to me.

speaker: None
text: If I wanted to drive that away I'd have to get rid of me.

speaker: None
text: There's an omen contained in that.

speaker: None
text: A mechanism buried inside of me.

speaker: None
text: A mechanism buried inside of you.

speaker: None
text: I switch off the light and leave the bathroom.

speaker: None
text: A heavy, damp stillness lies over the house.

speaker: None
text: The whispers of people who don't exist, the breath of the dead.

speaker: None
text: I look around, standing stock-still, and take a deep breath.

speaker: None
text: The clock shows three p. m., the two hands cold and distant.

speaker: None
text: They're pretending to be noncommittal, but I know they're not on my side.

speaker: None
text: It's nearly time for me to say good-bye.

speaker: None
text: I pick up my backpack and slip it over my shoulders.

speaker: None
text: I've carried it any number of times, but now it feels so much heavier.

speaker: None
text: Shikoku, I decide.

speaker: None
text: That's where I'll go.

speaker: None
text: There's no particular reason it has to be Shikoku, only that studying the map I got the feeling that's where I should head.

speaker: None
text: The more I look at the map--actually every time I study it--the more I feel Shikoku tugging at me.

speaker: None
text: It's far south of Tokyo, separated from the mainland by water, with a warm climate.

speaker: None
text: I've never been there, have no friends or relatives there, so if somebody started looking for me--which I kind of doubt--Shikoku would be the last place they'd think of.

speaker: None
text: I pick up the ticket I'd reserved at the counter and climb aboard the night bus.

speaker: None
text: This is the cheapest way to get to Takamatsu--just a shade over ninety bucks.

speaker: None
text: Nobody pays me any attention, asks how old I am, or gives me a second look.

speaker: None
text: The bus driver mechanically checks my ticket.

speaker: None
text: Only a third of the seats are taken.

speaker: None
text: Most passengers are traveling alone, like me, and the bus is strangely silent.

speaker: None
text: It's a long trip to Takamatsu, ten hours according to the schedule, and we'll be arriving early in the morning.

speaker: None
text: But I don't mind.

speaker: None
text: I've got plenty of time.

speaker: None
text: The bus pulls out of the station at eight, and I push my seat back.

speaker: None
text: No sooner do I settle down than my consciousness, like a battery that's lost its charge, starts to fade away, and I fall asleep.

speaker: None
text: Sometime in the middle of the night a hard rain begins to fall.

speaker: None
text: I wake up every once in a while, part the chintzy curtain at the window, and gaze out at the highway rushing by.

speaker: None
text: Raindrops beat against the glass, blurring streetlights alongside the road that stretch off into the distance at identical intervals like they were set down to measure the earth.

speaker: None
text: A new light rushes up close and in an instant fades off behind us.

speaker: None
text: I check my watch and see it's past midnight.

speaker: None
text: Automatically shoved to the front, my fifteenth birthday makes its appearance.

speaker: None
text: Hey, happy birthday, the boy named Crow says.

speaker: None
text: Thanks, I reply.

speaker: None
text: The omen is still with me, though, like a shadow.

speaker: None
text: I check to make sure the wall around me is still in place.

speaker: None
text: Then I close the curtain and fall back asleep.

speaker: None
text: 2 T he following document, classified Top Secret by the U.S. Department of Defense, was released to the public in 1986 through the Freedom of Information Act.

speaker: None
text: The document is now kept in the National Archives in Washington, D.C., and can be accessed there.

speaker: None
text: The investigations recorded here were carried out under the direction of Major James P. Warren from March to April 1946.

speaker: None
text: The field investigation in [name deleted] County, Yamanashi Prefecture, was conducted by Second Lieutenant Robert O'Connor and Master Sergeant Harold Katayama.

speaker: None
text: The interrogator in all interviews was Lt. O'Connor.

speaker: None
text: Sgt.

speaker: None
text: Katayama handled the Japanese interpreting, and Private William Cohen prepared the documents.

speaker: None
text: Interviews were conducted over a twelve-day period in the reception room of the [name deleted] Town town hall in Yamanashi Prefecture.

speaker: None
text: The following witnesses responded individually to Lt. O'Connor's questions: a female teacher at the [deleted] Town [deleted] County public school, a doctor residing in the same town, two patrolmen assigned to the local police precinct, and six children.

speaker: None
text: The appended 1:10,000 and 1:2,000 maps of the area in question were provided by the Topographic Institute of the Ministry of Home Affairs.

speaker: None
text: U.S. ARMY INTELLIGENCE SECTION (MIS) REPORT Dated: May 12, 1946 Title: Report on the Rice Bowl Hill Incident, 1944 Document Number: PTYX-722- 8936745-42213-WWN The following is a taped interview with Setsuko Okamochi (26), teacher in charge of the fourth-grade B class at the public school in [deleted] Town, [deleted] County.

speaker: None
text: Materials related to the interview can be accessed using application number PTYX-722-SQ-118.

speaker: None
text: Impressions of the interviewer, Lt. Robert O'Connor: Setsuko Okamochi is an attractive, petite woman.

speaker: None
text: Intelligent and responsible, she responded to the questions accurately and honestly.

speaker: None
text: She still seems slightly in shock, though, from the incident.

speaker: None
text: As she searched her memory she grew very tense at times, and whenever this happened she had a tendency to speak more slowly.

speaker: None
text: I think it must have been just after ten in the morning when I saw a silver light far up in the sky.

speaker: None
text: A brilliant flash of silver.

speaker: None
text: It was a clear blue sky, and the light was so bright all we could see was that silver, duralumin-like object.

speaker: None
text: But we couldn't make out the shape, since it was too far up.

speaker: None
text: I assumed that they couldn't see us either, so we weren't afraid of being attacked or having bombs suddenly rain down on us.

speaker: None

speaker: None

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: --According to military records no U.S. bombers or any other kind of aircraft were flying over that region at the time, that is, around ten a.m. on November 7, 1944.

speaker: None
text: But I saw it clearly, and so did the sixteen children in my class.

speaker: None
text: All of us thought it had to be a B-29.

speaker: None
text: We'd all seen many formations of B-29s, and those are the only kind of planes that could possibly fly that high.

speaker: None
text: There was a small airbase in our prefecture, and I'd occasionally seen Japanese planes flying, but they were all small and could never fly as high as what I saw.

speaker: None
text: Besides, the way duralumin reflects light is different from other types of metal, and the only planes made out of that are B-29s.

speaker: None

text: From what I heard later, he was guarding an ammunition dump just outside Manila when it was hit by American shells and blew up, killing him.

text: Eight boys and eight girls.

text: We set out from the school at nine in the morning.

text: It was a typical school outing, so everyone carried canteens and lunches with them.

speaker: None
text: We had nothing in particular we were planning to study; we were just going up into the hills to gather mushrooms and edible wild plants.

speaker: None
text: The area around where we lived was farmland, so we weren't that badly off in terms of food--which isn't to say we had plenty to eat.

speaker: None
text: There was a strict rationing system in place and most of us were hungry all the time.

speaker: None
text: So the children were encouraged to hunt for food wherever they could find it.

speaker: None
text: The country was at war, after all, and food took priority over studying.

speaker: None
text: Everyone went on this kind of school outing--outdoor study sessions, as they were called.

speaker: None
text: Since our school was surrounded by hills and woods, there were a lot of nice spots we used to go to.

speaker: None
text: I think we were blessed in that sense.

speaker: None
text: People in cities were all starving.

text: Supply routes from Taiwan and the continent had been cut off by this time and urban areas were suffering terribly from a lack of food and fuel.

text: Did they get along well with the local children?

text: They spoke differently, even dressed differently.

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: I'm not saying they bullied each other or got into fights, because they didn't.

speaker: None

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: You know how it is.

speaker: None
text: Still, you have to remember these are small children, and once they start hunting mushrooms they tend to forget this rule.

speaker: None
text: So I always made sure that as I looked for mushrooms myself I kept an eye on them, and a running head count.

text: There are a lot of highly toxic mushrooms around here, even ones that can be fatal.
