text: The girl's soon fast asleep, and as the bus sways through each curve her head leans against my shoulder, finally coming to a rest there.

speaker: None
text: Mouth closed, she's breathing quietly through her nose, the breath grazing my shoulder at regular beats.

speaker: None
text: I look down and catch a glimpse of her bra strap through the collar of her crewneck shirt, a thin, cream-colored strap.

speaker: None
text: I picture the delicate fabric at the end of that strap.

speaker: None
text: The soft breasts beneath.

speaker: None
text: The pink nipples taut under my fingertips.

speaker: None
text: Not that I'm trying to imagine all this, but I can't help it.

speaker: None
text: And--no surprise--I get a massive hard-on.

speaker: None
text: So rigid it makes me wonder how any part of your body could ever get so rock hard.

speaker: None
text: Just then a thought hits me.

speaker: None
text: Maybe--just maybe--this girl's my sister.

speaker: None
text: She's about the right age.

speaker: None
text: Her odd looks aren't at all like the girl in the photo, but you can't always count on that.

speaker: None
text: Depending on how they're taken people sometimes look totally different.

speaker: None
text: She said she has a brother my age who she hasn't seen in ages.

speaker: None
text: Couldn't that brother be me--in theory, at least?

speaker: None
text: I stare at her chest.

speaker: None
text: As she breathes, the rounded peaks move up and down like the swell of waves, somehow reminding me of rain falling softly on a broad stretch of sea.

speaker: None
text: I'm the lonely voyager standing on deck, and she's the sea.

speaker: None
text: The sky is a blanket of gray, merging with the gray sea off on the horizon.

speaker: None
text: It's hard to tell the difference between sea and sky.

speaker: None
text: Between voyager and sea.

speaker: None
text: Between reality and the workings of the heart.

speaker: None
text: The girl wears two rings on her fingers, neither of which is a wedding or engagement ring, just cheap things you find at those little boutiques girls shop at.

speaker: None
text: Her fingers are long and thin but look strong, the nails are short and nicely trimmed with a light pink polish.

speaker: None
text: Her hands are resting lightly on the knees thrust out from her miniskirt.

speaker: None
text: I want to touch those hands, but of course I don't.

speaker: None
text: Asleep, she looks like a young child.

speaker: None
text: One pointy ear peeks out from the strands of hair like a little mushroom, looking strangely fragile.

speaker: None
text: I shut my book and look for a while at the passing scenery.

speaker: None
text: But very soon, before I realize it, I fall asleep myself.

speaker: None
text: 4 U.S. ARMY INTELLIGENCE SECTION (MIS) REPORT Dated: May 12, 1946 Title: Report on the Rice Bowl Hill Incident, 1944 Document Number: PTYX-722-8936745-42216-WWN The following is a taped interview with Doctor Juichi Nakazawa (53), who ran an internal medicine clinic in [name deleted] Town at the time of the incident.

speaker: None
text: Materials related to the interview can be accessed using application number PTYX-722-SQ-162 to 183.

speaker: None
text: Impressions of the interviewer Lt. Robert O'Connor: Doctor Nakazawa is so big boned and dark skinned he looks more like a farm foreman than a doctor.

speaker: None
text: He has a calm manner but is very brisk and concise and says exactly what's on his mind.

speaker: None
text: Behind his glasses his eyes have a very sharp, alert look, and his memory seems reliable.

speaker: None
text: That's correct--at eleven a.m. on November 7, 1944, I received a phone call from the assistant principal at the local elementary school.

speaker: None
text: I used to be the school doctor, or something close to it, so that's why they contacted me first.

speaker: None
text: The assistant principal was terribly upset.

speaker: None
text: He told me that an entire class had lost consciousness while on an outing in the hills to pick mushrooms.

speaker: None
text: According to him they were totally unconscious.

speaker: None
text: Only the teacher in charge had remained conscious, and she'd run back to school for help just then.

speaker: None
text: She was so flustered I couldn't grasp the whole situation, though one fact did come through loud and clear: sixteen children had collapsed in the woods.

speaker: None
text: The kids were out picking mushrooms, so of course my first thought was that they'd eaten some poisonous ones and been paralyzed.

speaker: None
text: If that were the case it'd be difficult to treat.

speaker: None
text: Different varieties of mushrooms have different toxicity levels, and the treatments vary.

speaker: None
text: The most we could do at the moment would be to pump out their stomachs.

speaker: None
text: In the case of highly toxic varieties, though, the poison might enter the bloodstream quickly and we might be too late.

speaker: None
text: Around here, several people a year die from poison mushrooms.

speaker: None
text: I stuffed some emergency medicine in my bag and rode my bike over to the school as fast as I could.

speaker: None
text: The police had been contacted and two policemen were already there.

speaker: None
text: We knew we had to get the unconscious kids back to town and would need all the help we could get.

speaker: None
text: Most of the young men were away at war, though, so we set off with the best we had--myself, the two policemen, an elderly male teacher, the assistant principal and principal, the school janitor.

speaker: None
text: And of course the homeroom teacher who'd been with the kids.

speaker: None
text: We grabbed whatever bicycles we could find, but there weren't enough, so some of us rode two to a bike.

speaker: None
text: #NAME?

speaker: None
text: It was 11:55.

speaker: None
text: I remember since I happened to glance at my watch when we got there.

speaker: None
text: We rode our bicycles to the bottom of the hill, as far as we could go, then climbed the rest of the way on foot.

speaker: None
text: By the time I arrived several children had partially regained consciousness.

speaker: None
text: Three or four of them, as I recall.

speaker: None
text: But they weren't fully conscious--sort of dizzily on all fours.

speaker: None
text: The rest of the children were still collapsed.

speaker: None
text: After a while some of the others began to come around, their bodies undulating like so many big worms.

speaker: None
text: It was a very strange sight.

speaker: None
text: The children had collapsed in an odd, flat, open space in the woods where it looked like all the trees had been neatly removed, with autumn sunlight shining down brightly.

speaker: None
text: And here you had, in this spot or at the edges of it, sixteen elementary-school kids scattered about prostrate on the ground, some of them starting to move, some of them completely still.

speaker: None
text: The whole thing reminded me of some weird avant-garde play.

speaker: None
text: For a moment I forgot that I was supposed to treat the kids and just stood there, frozen, staring at the scene.

speaker: None
text: Not just myself--everyone in the rescue group reacted the same, paralyzed for a while by what they saw.

speaker: None
text: This might be a strange way of putting it, perhaps, but it was like some mistake had occurred that allowed us to see a sight people should never see.

speaker: None
text: It was wartime, and I was always mentally prepared, as a physician, to deal with whatever came, in the remote possibility that something awful would occur way out here in the country.

speaker: None
text: Prepared as a citizen of Japan to calmly do my duty if the need arose.

speaker: None
text: But when I saw this scene in the woods I literally froze.

speaker: None
text: I soon snapped out of it, and picked up one of the children, a little girl.

speaker: None
text: Her body had no strength in it at all and was limp as a rag doll.

speaker: None
text: Her breathing was steady but she was still unconscious.

speaker: None
text: Her eyes, though, were open, tracking something back and forth.

speaker: None
text: I pulled a small flashlight out of my bag and shined it on her pupils.

speaker: None
text: Completely unreactive.

speaker: None
text: Her eyes were functioning, watching something, yet showed no response to light.

speaker: None
text: I picked up several other children and examined them and they were all exactly the same, unresponsive.

speaker: None
text: I found this quite odd.

speaker: None
text: I next checked their pulse and temperature.

speaker: None
text: Their pulses were between 50 and 55, and all of them had temperatures just below 97 degrees.

speaker: None
text: Somewhere around 96 degrees or thereabouts, as I recall.

speaker: None
text: That's correct--for children of that age this pulse rate is well below normal, the body temperature over one degree below average.

speaker: None
text: I smelled their breath, but there was nothing out of the ordinary.

speaker: None
text: Likewise with their throats and tongues.

speaker: None
text: I immediately ascertained these weren't the symptoms of food poisoning.

speaker: None
text: Nobody had vomited or suffered diarrhea, and none of them seemed to be in any pain.

speaker: None
text: If the children had eaten something bad you could expect--with this much time having elapsed--the onset of at least one of these symptoms.

speaker: None
text: I heaved a sigh of relief that it wasn't food poisoning.

speaker: None
text: But then I was stumped, since I hadn't a clue what was wrong with them.

speaker: None
text: The symptoms were similar to sunstroke.

speaker: None
text: Kids often collapse from this in the summer.

speaker: None
text: It's like it's contagious--once one of them collapses their friends all do the same, one after the other.

speaker: None
text: But this was November, in a cool woods, no less.

speaker: None
text: One or two getting sunstroke is one thing, but sixteen children simultaneously coming down with it was out of the question.

speaker: None
text: My next thought was some kind of poison gas or nerve gas, either naturally occurring or man-made.

speaker: None
text: But how in the world could gas appear in the middle of the woods in such a remote part of the country?

speaker: None
text: I couldn't account for it.

speaker: None
text: Poison gas, though, would logically explain what I saw that day.

speaker: None
text: Everyone breathed it in, went unconscious, and collapsed on the spot.

speaker: None
text: The homeroom teacher didn't collapse because the concentration of gas wasn't strong enough to affect an adult.

speaker: None
text: But when it came to treating the children, I was totally lost.

speaker: None
text: I'm just a simple country doctor and have no special expertise in poison gasses, so I was out of my league.

speaker: None
text: We were out in this remote town and I couldn't very well ring up a specialist.

speaker: None
text: Very gradually, in fact, some of the children were getting better, and I figured that perhaps with time they would all regain consciousness.

speaker: None
text: I know it's an overly optimistic view, but at the time I couldn't think of anything else to do.

speaker: None
text: So I suggested that we just let them lie there quietly for a while and see what developed.

speaker: None
text: #NAME?

speaker: None
text: I was concerned about that myself, so I took several deep breaths to see if I could detect any unusual odor.

speaker: None
text: But it was just the ordinary smell of a woods in the hills.

speaker: None
text: It was a bracing scent, the fragrance of trees.

speaker: None
text: Nothing unusual about the plants and flowers around there, either.

speaker: None
text: Nothing had changed shape or been discolored.

speaker: None
text: One by one I examined the mushrooms the children had been picking.

speaker: None
text: There weren't all that many, which led me to conclude that they'd collapsed not long after they began picking them.

speaker: None
text: All of them were typical edible mushrooms.

speaker: None
text: I've been a doctor here for some time and am quite familiar with the different varieties.

speaker: None
text: Of course to be on the safe side I collected them all and took them back and had a specialist examine them.

speaker: None
text: But as far as I could tell, they were all ordinary, edible mushrooms.

speaker: None
text: --You said the unconscious children's eyes moved back and forth, but did you notice any other unusual symptoms or reactions?

speaker: None
text: For instance, the size of their pupils, the color of the whites of their eyes, the frequency of their blinking?

speaker: None
text: No.

speaker: None
text: Other than their eyes moving back and forth like a searchlight, there was nothing out of the ordinary.

speaker: None
text: All other functions were completely normal.

speaker: None
text: The children were looking at something.

speaker: None
text: To put a finer point on it, the children weren't looking at what we could see, but something we couldn't.

speaker: None
text: It was more like they were observing something rather than just looking at it.

speaker: None
text: They were essentially expressionless, but overall they seemed calm, not afraid or in any pain.

speaker: None
text: That's also one of the reasons I decided to just let them lie there and see how things played out.

speaker: None
text: I decided if they're not in any pain, then just let them be for a while.

speaker: None
text: #NAME?

speaker: None
text: Yes, they did.

speaker: None
text: But like me they couldn't figure out how it was possible.

speaker: None
text: I mean, no one had ever heard of somebody going on a hike in the woods and ending up getting gassed.

speaker: None
text: Then one of the people there--the assistant principal, I believe it was--said it might have been gas dropped by the Americans.

speaker: None
text: They must have dropped a bomb with poison gas, he said.

speaker: None
text: The homeroom teacher recalled seeing what looked like a B-29 in the sky just before they started up the hill, flying right overhead.

speaker: None
text: That's it!

speaker: None
text: everyone said, some new poison gas bomb the Americans developed.

speaker: None
text: Rumors about the Americans developing a new kind of bomb had even reached our neck of the woods.

speaker: None
text: But why would the Americans drop their newest weapon in such an out-of-the-way place?

speaker: None
text: That we couldn't explain.

speaker: None
text: But mistakes are part of life, and some things we aren't meant to understand, I suppose.

speaker: None
text: #NAME?

speaker: None
text: They did.

speaker: None
text: I can't tell you how relieved I was.

speaker: None
text: At first they started squirming around, then they sat up unsteadily, gradually regaining consciousness.

speaker: None
text: No one complained of any pain during this process.

speaker: None
text: It was all very quiet, like they were waking up from a deep sleep.

speaker: None
text: And as they regained consciousness their eye movements became normal again.

speaker: None
text: They showed normal reactions to light when I shined a flashlight in their eyes.

speaker: None
text: It took some time, though, for them to be able to speak again--just like you are when you first wake up.

speaker: None
text: We asked each of the children what had happened, but they looked dumbfounded, like we were asking about something they didn't remember taking place.

speaker: None
text: Going up the hill, starting to gather mushrooms--that much they recalled.

speaker: None
text: Everything after that was a total blank.

speaker: None
text: They had no sense of any time passing between then and now.

speaker: None
text: They start gathering mushrooms, then the curtain falls, and here they are lying on the ground, surrounded by all these adults.

speaker: None
text: The children couldn't figure out why we were all upset, staring at them with these worried looks on our faces.

speaker: None
text: They seemed more afraid of us than anything else.

speaker: None
text: Sadly, there was one child, a boy, who didn't regain consciousness.

speaker: None
text: One of the children evacuated from Tokyo.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Satoru Nakata, I believe his name was.

speaker: None
text: A small, pale little boy.

speaker: None
text: He was the only one who remained unconscious.

speaker: None
text: He just lay there on the ground, his eyes moving back and forth.

speaker: None
text: We had to carry him back down the hill.

speaker: None
text: The other children walked back down like nothing had happened.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: #NAME?

speaker: None
text: As far as any outward signs at least, no, they displayed no unusual symptoms.

speaker: None
text: No one complained of pain or discomfort.

speaker: None
text: As soon as we got back to the school I brought the children into the nurse's room one by one and examined them--took their temperature, listened to their heart with a stethoscope, checked their vision.

speaker: None
text: Whatever I was able to do at the time I did.

speaker: None
text: I had them solve some simple arithmetic problems, stand on one foot with their eyes closed, things like that.

speaker: None
text: Physically they were fine.

speaker: None
text: They didn't seem tired and had healthy appetites.

speaker: None
text: They'd missed lunch so they all said they were hungry.

speaker: None
text: We gave them rice balls to eat, and they gobbled them up.

speaker: None
text: A few days later I stopped by the school to observe how the children were doing.

speaker: None
text: I called a few of them into the nurse's room and questioned them.

speaker: None
text: Again, though, everything seemed fine.

speaker: None
text: No traces remained, physically or emotionally, from their strange experience.

speaker: None
text: They couldn't even remember that it had happened.

speaker: None
text: Their lives were completely back to normal, unaffected by the incident.

speaker: None
text: They attended class as usual, sang songs, played outside during recess, everything normal kids did.

speaker: None
text: Their homeroom teacher, however, was a different story: she still seemed in shock.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: But that one boy, Nakata, didn't regain consciousness, so the following day he was taken to the university hospital in Kofu.

speaker: None
text: After that he was transferred to a military hospital, and never came back to our town again.

speaker: None
text: I never heard what became of him.

speaker: None
text: This incident never made the newspapers.

speaker: None
text: My guess is the authorities decided it would only cause unrest, so they banned any mention of it.

speaker: None
text: You have to remember that during the war the military tried to squelch whatever they saw as groundless rumors.

speaker: None
text: The war wasn't going well, with the military retreating on the southern front, suicide attacks one after the other, air raids on cities getting worse all the time.

speaker: None
text: The military was especially afraid of any antiwar or pacifist sentiment cropping up among the populace.

speaker: None
text: A few days after the incident the police came calling and warned us that under no circumstances were we to talk about what we'd seen.

speaker: None
text: The whole thing was an odd, unpleasant affair.

speaker: None
text: Even to this day it's like a weight pressing down on me.

speaker: None
text: 5 I'm asleep when our bus drives across the huge new bridge over the Inland Sea.

speaker: None
text: I'd seen the bridge only on maps and had been looking forward to seeing it for real.

speaker: None
text: Somebody gently taps me on the shoulder and I wake up.

speaker: None
text: Hey, we're here, the girl says.

speaker: None
text: I stretch, rub my eyes with the back of my hand, and look out the window.

speaker: None
text: Sure enough, the bus is just pulling into what looks like the square in front of a station.

speaker: None
text: Fresh morning sunlight lights up the scene.

speaker: None
text: Almost blinding, but gentle somehow, the light is different from what I was used to in Tokyo.

speaker: None
text: I glance at my watch .6:32.

speaker: None
text: Gosh, what a long trip, she says tiredly.

speaker: None
text: I thought my lower back was going to give out.

speaker: None
text: And my neck's killing me.

speaker: None
text: You aren't going to catch me on an all-night bus again.

speaker: None
text: I'm taking the plane from now on, even if it's more expensive.

speaker: None
text: Turbulence, hijackings--I don't care.

speaker: None
text: Give me a plane any day.

speaker: None
text: I lower her suitcase and my backpack from the overhead rack.

speaker: None
text: What's your name?

speaker: None
text: I ask.

speaker: None
text: My name?

speaker: None
text: Yeah.

speaker: Sakura
text: Sakura," she says.

speaker: None
text: What about you?

speaker: Kafka Tamura
text: Kafka Tamura," I reply.

speaker: Kafka Tamura
text: Kafka Tamura, she muses.

speaker: None
text: Weird name.

speaker: None
text: Easy to remember, though.

speaker: None
text: I nod.

speaker: None
text: Becoming a different person might be hard, but taking on a different name is a cinch.

speaker: None
text: She gets off the bus, sets her suitcase on the ground, and plunks herself down on top, then pulls a notebook from a pocket in her small backpack, scribbles down something, rips the page out, and hands it to me.

speaker: None
text: A phone number, by the looks of it.

speaker: None
text: My cell phone number, she says with a wry expression.

speaker: None
text: I'm staying at my friend's place for a while, but if you ever feel like seeing somebody, give me a call.

speaker: None
text: We can go out for a bite or whatever.

speaker: None
text: Don't be a stranger, okay?

speaker: None
text: 'Even chance meetings'... how does the rest of that go?

speaker: None
text: 'Are the result of karma.

speaker: None
text: '" "Right, right," she says.

speaker: None
text: But what does it mean?

speaker: None
text: That things in life are fated by our previous lives.

speaker: None
text: That even in the smallest events there's no such thing as coincidence.

speaker: None
text: She sits there on her yellow suitcase, notebook in hand, giving it some thought.

speaker: None
text: Hmm... that's a kind of philosophy, isn't it.

speaker: None
text: Not such a bad way of thinking about life.

speaker: None
text: Sort of a reincarnation, New Age kind of thing.

speaker: Kafka Tamura
text: But, Kafka, remember this, okay?

speaker: None
text: I don't go around giving my cell phone number to just anybody.

speaker: None
text: You know what I mean?

speaker: None
text: I appreciate it, I tell her.

speaker: None
text: I fold up the piece of paper and stick it in the pocket of my windbreaker.

speaker: None
text: Thinking better of it, I transfer it to my wallet.

speaker: None
text: So how long'll you be in Takamatsu?

speaker: Sakura
text: Sakura asks.

speaker: None
text: I don't know yet, I say.

speaker: None
text: It depends on how things go.

speaker: None
text: She gazes intently at me, her head tilted slightly to one side.

speaker: None
text: Okay, whatever, she might be thinking.

speaker: None
text: She climbs into a cab, gives a little wave, and takes off.

speaker: None
text: Once again I'm all alone.

speaker: Sakura
text: Sakura, I think--not my sister's name.

speaker: None
text: But names are changed easily enough.

speaker: None
text: Especially when you're trying to try to run away from somebody.

speaker: None
text: I have a reservation at a business hotel in Takamatsu.

speaker: None
text: The YMCA in Tokyo had told me about the place, and through them I got a discount on the room.

speaker: None
text: But that's only for the first three days, then it goes back to the normal room rate.

speaker: None
text: If I really wanted to save money, I could just sack out on a bench in front of the station, or since it's still warm out, I could sleep in my sleeping bag in a park somewhere.

speaker: None
text: But then the cops will come and card me--the one thing I have to avoid at all costs.

speaker: None
text: That's why I went for the hotel reservation, at least for three days.

speaker: None
text: After that I'll figure something out.

speaker: None
text: At the station I pop into the first little diner that catches my eye, and eat my fill of udon.

speaker: None
text: Born and raised in Tokyo, I haven't had much udon in my life.

speaker: None
text: But now I'm in Udon Central--Shikoku--and confronted with noodles like nothing I've ever seen.

speaker: None
text: They're chewy and fresh, and the soup smells great, really fragrant.

speaker: None
text: And talk about cheap.

speaker: None
text: It all tastes so good I order seconds, and for the first time in who knows how long, I'm happily stuffed.

speaker: None
text: Afterward I plop myself down on a bench in the plaza next to the station and gaze up at the sunny sky.

speaker: None
text: I'm free, I remind myself.

speaker: None
text: Like the clouds floating across the sky, I'm all by myself, totally free.

speaker: None
text: I decide to kill time till evening at a library.

speaker: None
text: Ever since I was little I've loved to spend time in the reading rooms of libraries, so I've come to Takamatsu armed with info on all the libraries in and around the city.

speaker: None
text: Think about it--a little kid who doesn't want to go home doesn't have many places he can go.

speaker: None
text: Coffee shops and movie theaters are offlimits.

speaker: None
text: That leaves only libraries, and they're perfect--no entrance fee, nobody getting all hot and bothered if a kid comes in.

speaker: None
text: You just sit down and read whatever you want.

speaker: None
text: I always rode my bike to the local public library after school.

speaker: None
text: Even on holidays that's where you'd find me.

speaker: None
text: I'd devour anything and everything--novels, biographies, histories, whatever was lying around.

speaker: None
text: Once I'd gone through all the children's books, I went on to the general stacks and books for adults.

speaker: None
text: I might not always get much out of them, but I forged on to the very last page.

speaker: None
text: When I got tired of reading I'd go into one of those listening booths with headphones and enjoy some music.

speaker: None
text: I had no idea about music so I just went down the row of CDs they had there, giving them all a listen.

speaker: None
text: That's how I got to know about Duke Ellington, the Beatles, and Led Zeppelin.

speaker: None
text: The library was like a second home.

speaker: None
text: Or maybe more like a real home, more than the place I lived in.

speaker: None
text: By going every day I got to know all the lady librarians who worked there.

speaker: None
text: They knew my name and always said hi.

speaker: None
text: I was painfully shy, though, and could barely reply.

speaker: None
text: Before coming to Takamatsu I found out some wealthy man from an old family in the suburbs had renovated his personal library into a private library open to the public.

speaker: None
text: The place has a lot of rare books, and I heard that the building itself and the surrounding garden were worth checking out.

speaker: None
text: I saw a photo of the place once in Taiyo magazine.

speaker: None
text: It's a large, Japanese-style house with this really elegant reading room that looks more like a parlor, where people are sitting with their books on comfortable-looking sofas.

speaker: None
text: For some reason that photo really stayed with me, and I wanted to see this in person if someday the chance came along.

speaker: None
text: The Komura Memorial Library, the place was called.

speaker: None
text: I go over to the tourist information booth at the station and ask how to get there.

speaker: None
text: A pleasant middle-aged lady marks the spot on a tourist map and gives me instructions on which train to take.

speaker: None
text: It's about a twenty-minute ride, she explains.

speaker: None
text: I thank her and study the schedule posted inside the station.

speaker: None
text: Trains run about every twenty minutes.

speaker: None
text: I have some time, so I pick up a takeout lunch at one of the little shops.

speaker: None
text: The train is just two little cars coupled together.

speaker: None
text: The tracks cut through a highrise shopping district, then past a mix of small shops and houses, factories and warehouses.

speaker: None
text: Next comes a park and an apartment building under construction.

speaker: None
text: I press my face against the window, drinking in the unfamiliar sights.

speaker: None
text: I've hardly ever been outside of Tokyo, and everything looks fresh and new.

speaker: None
text: The train I'm on, going out of town, is nearly empty this time of the morning, but the platforms on the other side are packed with junior and senior high school kids in summer uniforms, schoolbags slung across their shoulders.

speaker: None
text: All heading to school.

speaker: None
text: Not me, though.

speaker: None
text: I'm alone, going in the opposite direction.

speaker: None
text: We're on different tracks in more ways than one.

speaker: None
text: All of a sudden the air feels thin and something heavy is bearing down on my chest.

speaker: None
text: Am I really doing the right thing?

speaker: None
text: The thought makes me feel helpless, isolated.

speaker: None
text: I turn my back on the schoolkids and try not to look at them anymore.

speaker: None
text: The train runs along the sea for a time, then cuts inland.

speaker: None
text: We pass tall fields of corn, grapevines, tangerine trees growing on terraced hills.

speaker: None
text: An occasional irrigation pond sparkles in the sunlight.

speaker: None
text: A river winding through a flat stretch of land looks cool and inviting, an empty lot is overgrown with summer grasses.

speaker: None
text: At one point we pass a dog standing by the tracks, staring vacantly at the train rushing by.

speaker: None
text: Watching this scenery makes me feel warm and calm all over again.

speaker: None
text: You're going to be okay, I tell myself, taking a deep breath.

speaker: None
text: All you can do is forge on ahead.

speaker: None
text: At the station I follow the map and walk north past rows of old stores and houses.

speaker: None
text: Both sides of the street are lined with walls around people's homes.

speaker: None
text: I've never seen so many different kinds--black walls made out of boards, white walls, granite block walls, stone walls with hedges on top.

speaker: None
text: The whole place is still and silent, with no one else on the street.

speaker: None
text: Hardly any cars pass by.

speaker: None
text: The air smells like the sea, which must be nearby.

speaker: None
text: I listen carefully but can't hear any waves.

speaker: None
text: Far off, though, I hear the faint bee-like buzz of an electric saw, maybe from a construction site.

speaker: None
text: Small signs with arrows pointing toward the library line the road from the station, so I can't get lost.

speaker: None
text: Right in front of the Komura Memorial Library's imposing front gate stand two neatly trimmed plum trees.

speaker: None
text: Inside the gate a gravel path winds past other beautifully manicured bushes and trees--pines and magnolias, kerria and azaleas--with not a fallen leaf in sight.

speaker: None
text: A couple of stone lanterns peek out between the trees, as does a small pond.

speaker: None
text: Finally I get to the intricately designed entrance.

speaker: None
text: I come to a halt in front of the open front door, hesitating for a moment about going inside.

speaker: None
text: This place doesn't look like any library I've ever seen.

speaker: None
text: But having come all this way I might as well take the plunge.

speaker: None
text: Just inside the entrance a young man is sitting behind a counter where you check your bags.

speaker: None
text: I slough off my backpack, then take off my sunglasses and cap.

speaker: None
text: Is this your first visit?

speaker: None
text: he asks me in a relaxed, quiet voice.

speaker: None
text: It's slightly highpitched, but smooth and soothing.

speaker: None
text: I nod, but the words don't come.

speaker: None
text: The question takes me by surprise and makes me kind of tense.

speaker: None
text: A long, freshly sharpened pencil between his fingers, the young man gazes intently at my face for a while.

speaker: None
text: The pencil is yellow, with an eraser at the end.

speaker: None
text: The man's face is on the small side, his features regular.

speaker: None
text: Pretty, rather than handsome, might describe him best.

speaker: None
text: He's wearing a button-down white cotton shirt and olive green chinos, with not a single wrinkle on either.

speaker: None
text: When he looks down his longish hair falls over his brow, and occasionally he notices this and fingers it back.

speaker: None
text: His sleeves are rolled up to the elbows, revealing slender white wrists.

speaker: None
text: Delicately framed glasses nicely complement his features.

speaker: Oshima
text: The small plastic name tag pinned to his chest says Oshima.

speaker: None
text: Not exactly the type of librarian I'm used to.

speaker: None
text: Feel free to use the stacks, he tells me, "and if you find a book you'd like to read, just bring it to the reading room.

speaker: None
text: Rare books have a red seal on them, and for those you'll need to fill out a request card.

speaker: None
text: Over there to the right is the reference room.

speaker: None
text: There's a card index and a computer you can use to search for material.

speaker: None
text: We don't allow any books to be checked out.

speaker: None
text: We don't carry any magazines or newspapers.

speaker: None
text: No cameras are allowed.

speaker: None
text: And neither is making copies of anything.

speaker: None
text: All food and beverages should be consumed outside on the benches.

speaker: None
text: And we close at five.

speaker: None
text: He lays his pencil on the desk and adds, Are you in high school?

speaker: None
text: Yes, I am," I say after taking a deep breath.

speaker: None
text: This library is a little different from the ones you're probably used to, he says.

speaker: None
text: We specialize in certain genres of books, mainly old books by tanka and haiku poets.

speaker: None
text: Naturally, we have a selection of general books as well.

speaker: None
text: Most of the people who ride the train all the way out here are doing research in those fields.

speaker: None
text: No one comes here to read the latest Stephen King novel.

speaker: None
text: We might get the occasional graduate student, but very seldom someone your age.

speaker: None
text: So--are you researching tanka or haiku, then?

speaker: None
text: No," I answer.

speaker: None
text: That's what I thought.

speaker: None
text: Is it still okay for me to use the library?

speaker: None
text: I ask timidly, trying to keep my voice from cracking.

speaker: None
text: Of course.

speaker: None
text: He smiles and places both hands on the desk.

speaker: None
text: This is a library, and anybody who wants to read is welcome.

speaker: None
text: This can be our little secret, but I'm not particularly fond of tanka or haiku myself.

speaker: None
text: It's a really beautiful building," I say.

speaker: None
text: He nods.

speaker: None
text: The Komura family's been a major sake producer since the Edo period, he explains, "and the previous head of the family was quite a bibliophile, nationally famous for scouring the country in search of books.

speaker: None
text: His father was himself a tanka poet, and many writers used to stop by here when they came to Shikoku.

speaker: None
text: Wakayama Bokusui, for instance, or Ishikawa Takuboku, and Shiga Naoya.

speaker: None
text: Some of them must have found it quite comfortable here, because they stayed a long time.

speaker: None
text: All in all, the family spared no expense when it came to the literary arts.

speaker: None
text: What usually happens with a family like that is eventually a descendant squanders the inheritance, but fortunately the Komuras avoided that fate.

speaker: None
text: They enjoyed their hobby, in its place, but made sure the family business did well.

speaker: None
text: So they were rich," I say, stating the obvious.

speaker: None
text: Very much so.

speaker: None
text: His lips curve ever so slightly.

speaker: None
text: They aren't as rich now as they were before the war, but they're still pretty wealthy.

speaker: None
text: Which is why they can maintain such a wonderful library.

speaker: None
text: Of course making it a foundation helps lower their inheritance tax, but that's another story.

speaker: None
text: If you're really interested in this building I suggest you take the little tour at two.

speaker: None
text: It's only once a week, on Tuesdays, which happens to be today.

speaker: None
text: There's a rather unique collection of paintings and drawings on the second floor, and the building itself is, architecturally, quite fascinating.

speaker: None
text: I know you'll enjoy it.

speaker: None
text: Thank you," I say.

speaker: None
text: You're quite welcome, his smile suggests.

speaker: None
text: He picks his pencil up again and starts tapping the eraser end on the desk like he's gently encouraging me.

speaker: None
text: Are you the one who does the tour?

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima smiles.

speaker: None
text: No, I'm just a lowly assistant, I'm afraid.

speaker: Miss Saeki
text: A lady named Miss Saeki is in charge here--my boss.

speaker: None
text: She's related to the Komuras and does the tour herself.

speaker: None
text: I know you'll like her.

speaker: None
text: She's a wonderful person.

speaker: None
text: I go into the high-ceilinged stacks and wander among the shelves, searching for a book that looks interesting.

speaker: None
text: Magnificent thick beams run across the ceiling of the room, and gentle early-summer sunlight is shining through the open window, the chatter of birds in the garden filtering in.

speaker: Oshima
text: The books in the shelves in front of me, sure enough, are just like Oshima said, mainly books of Japanese poetry.

speaker: None
text: Tanka and haiku, essays on poetry, biographies of various poets.

speaker: None
text: There are also a lot of books on local history.

speaker: None
text: A shelf farther back contains general humanities--collections of Japanese literature, world literature, and individual writers, classics, philosophy, drama, art history, sociology, history, biography, geography....

speaker: None
text: When I open them, most of the books have the smell of an earlier time leaking out between the pages--a special odor of the knowledge and emotions that for ages have been calmly resting between the covers.

speaker: None
text: Breathing it in, I glance through a few pages before returning each book to its shelf.

speaker: None
text: Finally I decide on a multivolume set, with beautiful covers, of the Burton translation of The Arabian Nights, pick out one volume, and take it back to the reading room.

speaker: None
text: I've been meaning to read this book.

speaker: None
text: Since the library has just opened for the day, there's no one else there and I have the elegant reading room all to myself.

speaker: None
text: It's exactly like in the photo in the magazine--roomy and comfortable, with a high ceiling.

speaker: None
text: Every once in a while a gentle breeze blows in through the open window, the white curtain rustling softly in air that has a hint of the sea.

speaker: None
text: And I love the comfortable sofa.

speaker: None
text: An old upright piano stands in a corner, and the whole place makes me feel like I'm in some friend's home.

speaker: None
text: As I relax on the sofa and gaze around the room a thought hits me: This is exactly the place I've been looking for forever.

speaker: None
text: A little hideaway in some sinkhole somewhere.

speaker: None
text: I'd always thought of it as a secret, imaginary place, and can barely believe that it actually exists.

speaker: None
text: I close my eyes and take a breath, and like a gentle cloud the wonder of it all settles over me.

speaker: None
text: I slowly stroke the creamish cover of the sofa, then stand up and walk over to the piano and lift the cover, laying all ten fingers down on the slightly yellowed keys.

speaker: None
text: I shut the cover and walk across the faded grape-patterned carpet to the window and test the antique handle that opens and closes it.

speaker: None
text: I switch the floor lamp on and off, then check out all the paintings hanging on the walls.

speaker: None
text: Finally I plop back down on the sofa and pick up reading where I left off, focusing on The Arabian Nights for a while.

speaker: None
text: At noon I take my bottle of mineral water and box lunch out to the veranda that faces the garden and sit down to eat.

speaker: None
text: Different kinds of birds fly overhead, fluttering from one tree to the next or flying down to the pond to drink and groom themselves.

speaker: None
text: There are some I've never seen before.

speaker: None
text: A large brown cat makes an appearance, which is their signal to clear out of there, even though the cat looks like he couldn't care less about birds.

speaker: None
text: All he wants is to stretch out on the stepping stones and enjoy the warm sunlight.

speaker: None
text: Is your school closed today?

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima asks when I drop off my backpack on my way back to the reading room.

speaker: None
text: No, I reply, carefully choosing my words, "I just decided to take some time off.

speaker: None
text: Refusing to go to school," he says.

speaker: None
text: I guess so.

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima looks at me with great interest.

speaker: None
text: You guess so.

speaker: None
text: I'm not refusing to go to school.

speaker: None
text: I just decided not to.

speaker: None
text: Very calmly, all on your own, you stopped going to school?

speaker: None
text: I merely nod.

speaker: None
text: I have no idea how to reply.

speaker: Oshima
text: According to Aristophanes in Plato's Symposium, in the ancient world of myth there were three types of people, Oshima says.

speaker: None
text: Have you heard about this?

speaker: None
text: No.

speaker: None
text: In ancient times people weren't just male or female, but one of three types: male/male, male/female, or female/female.

speaker: None
text: In other words, each person was made out of the components of two people.

speaker: None
text: Everyone was happy with this arrangement and never really gave it much thought.

speaker: None
text: But then God took a knife and cut everybody in half, right down the middle.

speaker: None
text: So after that the world was divided just into male and female, the upshot being that people spend their time running around trying to locate their missing other half.

speaker: None
text: Why did God do that?

speaker: None
text: Divide people into two?

speaker: None
text: You got me.

speaker: None
text: God works in mysterious ways.

speaker: None
text: There's that whole wrath-of-God thing, all that excessive idealism and so on.

speaker: None
text: My guess is it was punishment for something.

speaker: None
text: Like in the Bible.

speaker: None
text: Adam and Eve and the Fall and so forth.

speaker: None
text: Original sin," I say.

speaker: None
text: That's right, original sin.

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima holds his pencil between his middle and index fingers, twirling it ever so slightly as if testing the balance.

speaker: None
text: Anyway, my point is that it's really hard for people to live their lives alone.

speaker: None
text: Back in the reading room I return to The Tale of Abu-l-Hasan, the Wag," but my mind wanders away from the book.

speaker: None
text: Male/male, male/female, and female/female?

speaker: None
text: At two o'clock I lay down my book and get up from the sofa to join the tour of the building.

speaker: Miss Saeki
text: Miss Saeki, leading the tour, is a slim woman I'd guess is in her mid-forties.

speaker: None
text: She's a little on the tall side for someone of her generation.

speaker: None
text: She's wearing a blue halfsleeved dress and a cream-colored cardigan, and has excellent posture.

speaker: None
text: Her long hair is loosely tied back, her face very refined and intelligent looking, with beautiful eyes and a shadowy smile playing over her lips, a smile whose sense of completeness is indescribable.

speaker: None
text: It reminds me of a small, sunny spot, the special patch of sunlight you find only in some remote, secluded place.

speaker: None
text: My house back in Tokyo has one just like that in the garden, and ever since I was little I loved that bright little spot.

speaker: None
text: She makes a strong impression on me, making me feel wistful and nostalgic.

speaker: None
text: Wouldn't it be great if this were my mother?

speaker: None
text: But I think the same thing every time I run across a charming, middle-aged woman.

speaker: Miss Saeki
text: The chances that Miss Saeki's actually my mother are close to zero, I realize.

speaker: None
text: Still, since I have no idea what my mother looks like, or even her name, the possibility does exist, right?

speaker: None
text: There's nothing that rules it out completely.

speaker: None
text: The only other people taking the tour are a middle-aged couple from Osaka.

speaker: None
text: The wife is short and pudgy with glasses as thick as a Coke bottle.

speaker: None
text: The husband's a skinny guy with hair so stiff I bet he needs a wire brush to tame it.

speaker: None
text: With narrow eyes and a broad forehead, he reminds me of some statue on a southern island, eyes fixed on the horizon.

speaker: None
text: The wife keeps up a one-sided conversation, her husband just grunting out a monosyllable every once in a while to let her know he's still alive.

speaker: None
text: Other than that, he gives the occasional nod to show he's properly impressed or else mutters some fragmentary comment I can't catch.

speaker: None
text: Both of them are dressed more for mountain climbing than for visiting a library, each wearing a waterproof vest with a million pockets, sturdy lace-up boots, and hiking hats.

speaker: None
text: Maybe this is how they always dress when they go on a trip, who knows.

speaker: None
text: They seem okay--not that I'd want them as parents or anything--and I'm relieved not to be the only one taking the tour.

speaker: Oshima
text: Miss Saeki begins by explaining the library's history--basically the same story Oshima told me.

speaker: None
text: How they opened to the public the books and paintings the umpteenth head of the family had collected, devoting the library to the region's cultural development.

speaker: None
text: A foundation was set up based on the Komura fortune and now managed the library and occasionally sponsored lectures, chamber music concerts, and the like.

speaker: None
text: The building itself dated from the early Meiji period, when it was built to serve double duty as the family library and guesthouse.

speaker: None
text: In the Taisho period it was completely renovated as a two-story building, with the addition of magnificent guest rooms for visiting writers and artists.

speaker: None
text: From the Taisho to the early Showa period, many famous artists visited the Komuras, leaving behind mementos--poems, sketches, and paintings-- in gratitude for having been allowed to stay here.

speaker: Miss Saeki
text: You'll be able to view some selected items from this valuable collection in the second-floor gallery, Miss Saeki adds.

speaker: None
text: Before World War II, a vibrant local culture was established less through the efforts of local government than those of wealthy connoisseurs such as the Komura family.

speaker: None
text: They were, in short, patrons of the arts.

speaker: None
text: Kagawa Prefecture has produced quite a number of talented tanka and haiku poets, and one reason for this was the dedication with which the Komura family founded and supported the local art scene.

speaker: None
text: Quite a number of books, essays, and reminiscences have been published on the history of these fascinating artistic circles, all of which are in our reading room.

speaker: None
text: I hope you'll take the opportunity to look at them.

speaker: None
text: The heads of the Komura family down through the years have been well versed in the arts, with an especially refined appreciation of the truly excellent.

speaker: None
text: This might have run in the blood.

speaker: None
text: They were very discerning patrons of the arts, supporting artists with the highest aims who produced the most outstanding works.

speaker: None
text: But as you're surely aware, in the arts there is no such thing as an absolutely perfect eye.

speaker: None
text: Unfortunately, some exceptional artists did not win their favor or were not received by them as they deserved to be.

speaker: None
text: One of these was the haiku poet Taneda Santoka.

speaker: None
text: According to the guestbook, Santoka stayed here on numerous occasions, each time leaving behind poems and drawings.

speaker: None
text: The head of the family, however, called him a 'beggar and a braggart,' wouldn't have much to do with him, and in fact threw away most of these works.

speaker: None
text: What a terrible waste," the lady from Osaka says, apparently truly sorry to hear this.

speaker: None
text: Nowadays Santoka fetches a hefty price.

speaker: Miss Saeki
text: You're exactly right," Miss Saeki says, beaming.

speaker: None
text: But at the time, he was an unknown, so perhaps it couldn't be helped.

speaker: None
text: There are many things we only see clearly in retrospect.

speaker: None
text: You got that right," the husband pipes in.

speaker: Miss Saeki
text: After this Miss Saeki guides us around the first floor, showing us the stacks, the reading room, the rare-books collection.

speaker: None
text: When he built this library, the head of the family decided not to follow the simple and elegant style favored by artists in Kyoto, instead choosing a design more like a rustic dwelling.

speaker: None
text: Still, as you can see, in contrast to the bold structure of the building, the furnishings and picture frames are quite elaborate and luxurious.

speaker: None
text: The carving of these wooden panels, for instance, is very elegant.

speaker: None
text: All the finest master craftsmen in Shikoku were assembled to work on the construction.

speaker: None
text: Our little group starts upstairs, a vaulted ceiling soaring over the staircase.

speaker: None
text: The ebony railing's so highly polished it looks like you'll leave a mark if you touch it.

speaker: None
text: On a stained-glass window next to the landing, a deer stretches out its neck to nibble at some grapes.

speaker: None
text: There are two parlors on the second floor, as well as a spacious hall that in the past was probably lined with tatami for banquets and gatherings.

speaker: None
text: Now the floor is plain wood, and the walls are covered with framed calligraphy, hanging scrolls, and Japanesestyle paintings.

speaker: None
text: In the center, a glass case displays various mementos and the story behind each.

speaker: None
text: One parlor is in the Japanese style, the other Western.

speaker: None
text: The Western-style room contains a large writing desk and a swivel chair that look like someone's still using.

speaker: None
text: There's a line of pines outside the window behind the desk, and the horizon's faintly visible between the trees.

speaker: None
text: The couple from Osaka walks around the parlor, inspecting all the items, reading the explanations in the pamphlet.

speaker: None
text: Every time the wife makes a comment, the husband chimes in to second her opinion.

speaker: None
text: A lucky couple that agrees on everything.

speaker: None
text: The things on display don't do much for me, so I check out the details of the building's construction.

speaker: Miss Saeki
text: While I'm nosing around the Western parlor Miss Saeki comes up to me and says, "You can sit in that chair, if you'd like to.

speaker: None
text: Shiga Naoya and Tanizaki both sat there at one time or another.

speaker: None
text: Not that this is the same chair, of course.

speaker: None
text: I sit down on the swivel chair and quietly rest my hands on the desk.

speaker: None
text: How is it?

speaker: None
text: Feel like you could write something?

speaker: None
text: I blush a little and shake my head.

speaker: Miss Saeki
text: Miss Saeki laughs and goes back to the couple.

speaker: None
text: From the chair I watch how she carries herself, every motion natural and elegant.

speaker: None
text: I can't express it well, but there's definitely something special about it, as if her retreating figure is trying to tell me something she couldn't express while facing me.

speaker: None
text: But what this is, I haven't a clue.

speaker: None
text: Face it, I remind myself--there're tons of things you don't have a clue about.

speaker: None
text: Still seated, I give the room a once-over.

speaker: None
text: On the wall is an oil painting, apparently of the seashore nearby.

speaker: None
text: It's done in an old-fashioned style, but the colors are fresh and alive.

speaker: None
text: On top of the desk is a large ashtray and a lamp with a green lampshade.

speaker: None
text: I push the switch and, sure enough, the light comes on.

speaker: None
text: A black clock hangs on the opposite wall, an antique by the looks of it, though the hands tell the right time.

speaker: None
text: There are round spots worn here and there into the wooden floor, and it creaks slightly when you walk on it.

speaker: Miss Saeki
text: At the end of the tour the Osaka couple thanks Miss Saeki and disappears.

speaker: None
text: It turns out they're members of a tanka circle in the Kansai region.

speaker: None
text: I wonder what kind of poems they compose--the husband, especially.

speaker: None
text: Grunts and nods don't add up to poetry.

speaker: None
text: But maybe writing poetry brings out some hidden talent in the guy.

speaker: None
text: I return to the reading room and pick up where I'd left off in my book.

speaker: None
text: Over the afternoon a few other readers filter in, most of them with those reading glasses old people wear and that everybody looks the same in.

speaker: None
text: Time passes slowly.

speaker: None
text: Nobody says a word, everyone lost in quiet reading.

speaker: None
text: One person sits at a desk jotting down notes, but the rest are sitting there silently, not moving, totally absorbed.

speaker: None
text: Just like me.

speaker: None
text: At five o'clock I shut my book and put it back on the shelf.

speaker: None
text: At the exit I ask, "What time do you open in the morning?

speaker: Oshima
text: Eleven," Oshima replies.

speaker: None
text: Planning on coming back tomorrow?

speaker: None
text: If it's no bother.

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima narrows his eyes as he looks at me.

speaker: None
text: Of course not.

speaker: None
text: A library's a place for people who want to read.

speaker: None
text: I'd be happy if you came back.

speaker: None
text: I hope you don't mind my asking, but do you always carry that backpack with you?

speaker: None
text: It looks pretty heavy.

speaker: None
text: What in the world could be inside?

speaker: None
text: A stack of Krugerrands, perhaps?

speaker: None
text: I blush.

speaker: None
text: Don't worry--I'm not really trying to find out.

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima presses the eraser end of his pencil against his right temple.

speaker: None
text: Well, see you tomorrow.

speaker: None
text: Bye," I say.

speaker: None
text: Instead of raising his hand, he lifts his pencil in farewell.

speaker: None
text: I take the train back to Takamatsu Station.

speaker: None
text: For dinner I stop inside a cheap diner near the station and order chicken cutlet and a salad.

speaker: None
text: I have a second helping of rice and a glass of warm milk after the meal.

speaker: None
text: At a mini-mart outside I buy a bottle of mineral water and two rice balls in case I get hungry in the middle of the night, then start for my hotel.

speaker: None
text: I walk not too fast or too slow, at an ordinary pace just like everybody else, so no one notices me.

speaker: None
text: The hotel is pretty large, a typical second-rate business hotel.

speaker: Kafka Tamura
text: I fill in the register at the front desk, giving Kafka instead of my real first name, a phony address and age, and pay for one night.

speaker: None
text: I'm a little nervous, but none of the clerks seem suspicious.

speaker: None
text: Nobody yells out, Hey, we can see right through your ruse, you little fifteen-year-old runaway!

speaker: None
text: 8 U.S. ARMY INTELLIGENCE SECTION (MIS) REPORT Dated: May 12, 1946 Title: Report on the Rice Bowl Hill Incident, 1944 Document Number: PTYX-722-8936745- 42216-WWN T he following is a taped interview with Doctor Shigenori Tsukayama (52), professor in the Department of Psychiatry in the School of Medicine, Tokyo Imperial University, which took place over a three-hour span at the GHQ of the Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers.

speaker: None
text: Documentation related to the interview can be accessed using application number PTYX-722-SQ-267 to 291.

speaker: None
text: [Note: Documents 271 and 278 are missing.

speaker: None
text: ] Impressions of the interviewer, Lt. Robert O'Connor: Professor Tsukayama was quite calm and relaxed throughout the interview, as one might expect of an expert of his caliber.

speaker: None
text: He is one of the leading psychiatrists in Japan and has published a number of outstanding books on the subject.

speaker: None
text: Unlike most Japanese, he avoids vague statements, drawing a sharp distinction between facts and conjecture.

speaker: None
text: Before the war he was an exchange scholar at Stanford, and is quite fluent in English.

speaker: None
text: He is surely well liked and respected by many.

speaker: None
text: We were ordered by the military to immediately undertake an examination of the children in question.

speaker: None
text: It was the middle of November 1944.

speaker: None
text: It was quite unusual for us to receive requests or orders from the military.

speaker: None
text: The military, of course, had its own extensive medical branch, and being a self-contained entity that put a high priority on secrecy, they usually preferred to handle matters internally.

speaker: None
text: Apart from the rare times when they needed the special knowledge and techniques that only outside researchers or physicians had, they seldom appealed to civilian doctors or researchers.

speaker: None
text: Thus when they broached this we immediately surmised that something extraordinary had occurred.

speaker: None
text: Frankly, I didn't like to work under military directions.

speaker: None
text: In most cases their goals were strictly utilitarian, with no interest in pursuing truth in an academic sense, only arriving at conclusions that accorded with their preconceptions.

speaker: None
text: They weren't the type of people swayed by logic.

speaker: None
text: But it was wartime and we couldn't very well say no.

speaker: None
text: We had to keep quiet and do exactly as we were told.

speaker: None
text: We'd been continuing our research despite the American air raids.

speaker: None
text: Most of our undergrads and grad students, though, had been drafted.

speaker: None
text: Students in psychiatry weren't exempt for the draft, unfortunately.

speaker: None
text: When the order came from the military we dropped everything and took a train to [name deleted] in Yamanashi Prefecture.

speaker: None
text: There were three of us--myself and a colleague from the Psychiatry Department, as well as a research physician from the Department of Neurosurgery with whom we'd been conducting research.

speaker: None
text: As soon as we got there they warned us that what they were about to reveal was a military secret we could never divulge.

speaker: None
text: Then they told us about the incident that had occurred at the beginning of the month.

speaker: None
text: How sixteen schoolchildren had lost consciousness in the hills and fifteen of them had regained consciousness thereafter, with no memory of what had taken place.

speaker: None
text: One boy, they told us, hadn't regained consciousness and was still in a military hospital in Tokyo.

speaker: None
text: The military doctor who'd examined the children right after the incident, an internal medicine specialist named Major Toyama, gave us a detailed explanation about what had transpired.

speaker: None
text: Many army doctors are more like bureaucrats concerned with protecting their own little preserve than with medicine, but fortunately Major Toyama wasn't one of them.

speaker: None
text: He was honest and straightforward, and obviously a talented physician.

speaker: None
text: He never tried to use the fact that we were civilians to lord it over us or conceal anything from us, as some might do.

speaker: None
text: He provided all the details we needed, in a very professional manner, and showed us medical records that had been kept on the children.

speaker: None
text: He wanted to get to the bottom of this as much as anybody.

speaker: None
text: We were all quite impressed by him.

speaker: None
text: The most important fact we gleaned from the records was that, medically speaking, the incident had caused no lasting impact on the children.

speaker: None
text: From right after the event to the present day, the examinations and tests consistently indicated no internal or external abnormalities.

speaker: None
text: The children were leading healthy lives, just as they had before the incident.

speaker: None
text: Detailed examinations revealed that several of the children had parasites, but nothing out of the ordinary.

speaker: None
text: Otherwise they were completely asymptomatic--no headaches, nausea, pain, loss of appetite, insomnia, listlessness, diarrhea, nightmares.

speaker: None
text: Nothing.

speaker: None
text: The one notable thing was that the two-hour span during which the children had been unconscious in the hills was erased from their memory.

speaker: None
text: As if that part had been extracted in toto.

speaker: None
text: Rather than a memory loss, it was more a memory lack.

speaker: None
text: These aren't medical terms, and I'm using them for the sake of convenience, but there's a big difference between loss and lack.

speaker: None
text: I suppose it's like--well, imagine a train steaming down a track.

speaker: None
text: The freight's disappeared from one of the cars.

speaker: None
text: A car that's empty inside-- that's loss.

speaker: None
text: When the whole car itself has vanished, that's lack.

speaker: None
text: We discussed the possibility that the children had breathed in poison gas.

speaker: None
text: Dr. Toyama said that naturally they'd considered this.

speaker: None
text: That's why the military is involved, he told us, but it seems a remote possibility.

speaker: None
text: He then told us, Now this is a military secret, so you can't tell anyone.

speaker: None
text: The army is definitely developing poison gas and biological weapons, but this is carried out mainly by a special unit on the Chinese mainland, not in Japan itself.

speaker: None
text: It's too dangerous a project to attempt in a place as densely populated as Japan.

speaker: None
text: I can't tell you whether or not these sorts of weapons are stored anywhere in Japan, though I can assure you most definitely that they are not kept anywhere in Yamanashi Prefecture.

speaker: None
text: #NAME?

speaker: None
text: Correct.

speaker: None
text: He was very clear about that.

speaker: None
text: We basically had no choice except to believe him, but he sounded believable.

speaker: None
text: We also concluded that it was highly unlikely that poison gas had been dropped from a B-29.

speaker: None
text: If the Americans had actually developed such a weapon and decided to use it, they'd drop it on some large city where the effects would be massive.

speaker: None
text: Dropping a canister or two on such a remote place wouldn't allow them to ascertain what effects the weapon had.

speaker: None
text: Besides, even if you accepted the premise that a poison gas had been dropped on the spot, any gas that makes children fall unconscious for two hours with no other lasting effects would be worthless as military arsenal.

speaker: None
text: Also we knew that no poison gas, whether manmade or naturally occurring, would act like this, leaving no aftereffects whatsoever.

speaker: None
text: Especially when you're dealing with children, who are more sensitive and have a more delicate immune system than adults, there would have to be some aftereffects, particularly in the eyes or mucous membranes.

speaker: None
text: We crossed off food poisoning for the same reason.

speaker: None
text: So what we were left with were psychological problems, or problems dealing with brain function.

speaker: None
text: In a case like that, standard medical methodology wouldn't help at all in isolating the cause.

speaker: None
text: The effects would be invisible, something you couldn't quantify.

speaker: None
text: We finally understood why we had been called here by the military to consult.

speaker: None
text: We interviewed every child involved in the incident, as well as the homeroom teacher and attending physician.

speaker: None
text: Major Toyama also participated.

speaker: None
text: But these interviews yielded almost nothing new--we merely confirmed what the major had already told us.

speaker: None
text: The children had no memory whatsoever of the event.

speaker: None
text: They saw what looked like a plane glinting high up in the sky, climbed up Owan yama, and began hunting mushrooms.

speaker: None
text: Then there's a gap in time and the next thing they recall is lying on the ground, surrounded by a group of worried-looking teachers and policemen.

speaker: None
text: They felt fine, without any pain, discomfort, or nausea.

speaker: None
text: Their minds just felt a bit blank, as you do when you first wake up in the morning.

speaker: None
text: That was all.

speaker: None
text: Each child gave the same exact response.

speaker: None
text: After conducting these interviews we concluded that this was a case of mass hypnosis.

speaker: None
text: From the symptoms the homeroom teacher and school doctor observed at the scene, this hypothesis made the most sense.

speaker: None
text: The regular movement of the eyes, the slight lowering of respiration, heartbeat, and temperature, the lack of memory--it all fit.

speaker: None
text: The teacher alone didn't lose consciousness because for whatever reason what produced this mass hypnosis didn't affect adults.

speaker: None
text: We weren't able to pinpoint the cause, however.

speaker: None
text: Generally speaking, though, mass hypnotism requires two elements.

speaker: None
text: First, the group must be close-knit and homogeneous, and placed in restricted circumstances.

speaker: None
text: Secondly, something has to trigger the reaction, something that acts simultaneously on everyone.

speaker: None
text: In this case it might have been the glint of that airplane they saw.

speaker: None
text: This is just a hypothesis, mind you-- we weren't able to find any other candidates--and there may very well have been some other trigger that set it off.

speaker: None
text: I broached the idea of it being a case of mass hypnosis with Major Toyama, making it clear this was merely a conjecture.

speaker: None
text: My two colleagues generally concurred.

speaker: None
text: Coincidentally, this also happened to be indirectly related to a research topic we were investigating ourselves.

speaker: None
text: That does seem to fit the evidence, Major Toyama said after giving it some thought.

speaker: None
text: This is not my field, but it would appear to be the likeliest explanation.

speaker: None
text: But there's one thing I don't understand--what made them snap out of this mass hypnosis?

speaker: None
text: There'd have to be some sort of reverse triggering mechanism.

speaker: None
text: I really don't know, I admitted.

speaker: None
text: All I could do was speculate.

speaker: None
text: My hypothesis was this: There is a system in place which, after a certain amount of time passes, automatically breaks the spell.

speaker: None
text: Our bodies have strong defense mechanisms in place, and if an outside system takes over momentarily, once a certain amount of time has passed it's like an alarm bell goes off, activating an emergency system that deprograms this foreign object that blocks our built-in defenses--in this case the effects of mass hypnosis--and eliminates it.

speaker: None
text: Unfortunately, I don't have the materials in front of me, so I can't quote the exact figures, but as I told Major Toyama, there have been reports of similar incidents occurring abroad.

speaker: None
text: All of them are considered mysteries with no logical explanation.

speaker: None
text: A large number of children lose consciousness at the same time, and several hours later wake up without any memory of what happened.

speaker: None
text: This incident is quite unusual, in other words, but not without precedent.

speaker: None
text: One strange instance took place around 1930, in the outskirts of a small village in Devonshire, England.

speaker: None
text: For no apparent reason, a group of thirty junior high students walking down a country path fell to the ground, one after the other, and lost consciousness.

speaker: None
text: Several hours later, as if nothing had happened, they regained consciousness and walked back to school under their own steam.

speaker: None
text: A physician examined them right away but could find nothing medically wrong.

speaker: None
text: Not one of them could recall what had taken place.

speaker: None
text: At the end of the last century, a similar incident occurred in Australia.

speaker: None
text: Outside of Adelaide fifteen teenage girls from a private girls school were on an outing when all of them lost consciousness, and then regained it.

speaker: None
text: Again there were no injuries, no aftereffects.

speaker: None
text: It ended up classified as a case of heatstroke, but all of them had lost consciousness and recovered it at nearly the same time, and nobody showed symptoms of heatstroke, so the real cause remains a mystery.

speaker: None
text: Besides, it wasn't a particularly hot day when it occurred.

speaker: None
text: Probably there was no other accounting for what had taken place, so they decided this was the best explanation.

speaker: None
text: These cases share several things in common: they took place among a group of either young boys or girls, somewhat distant from their school, all of whom lost consciousness essentially simultaneously and then regained it about the same time, with no one displaying any aftereffects.

speaker: None
text: It's reported that some of the adults who happened to be with the children also lost consciousness, and some did not.

speaker: None
text: Each case was different in that regard.

speaker: None
text: There are other similar incidents, but these two are the best documented, and thus are representative cases in the literature of this phenomenon.

speaker: None
text: This recent instance in Yamanashi Prefecture, however, contains one element that differentiates it from the rest: namely that one boy did not regain consciousness.

speaker: None
text: This child is the key to unlocking the truth to this whole event.

speaker: None
text: We returned to Tokyo after our interviews in Yamanashi and went straight to the army hospital where the boy was being cared for.

speaker: None
text: #NAME?

speaker: None
text: That's my understanding.

speaker: None
text: But Major Toyama would know more about this, and I suggest you ask him directly.

speaker: None
text: --Major Toyama was killed in Tokyo in March 1945, in the line of duty, during an air raid.

speaker: None
text: I'm very sorry to hear that.

speaker: None
text: We lost so many promising people in the war.

speaker: None
text: #NAME?

speaker: None
text: They couldn't determine the cause, but they decided, didn't they, that it was unrelated to the war?

speaker: None
text: Yes, I believe that's true.

speaker: None
text: At this point they'd concluded their investigation into the matter.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: But the boy, Nakata, was allowed to remain in the military hospital, since Major Toyama was personally interested in the case and had some connections there.

speaker: None
text: Thus we were able to go to the military hospital every day, and take turns staying overnight to investigate this unconscious boy's case further, from a number of angles.

speaker: None
text: Though unconscious, the boy's bodily functions nevertheless continued normally.

speaker: None
text: He was given nutrients intravenously and discharged urine at regular intervals.

speaker: None
text: He shut his eyes at night and went to sleep when we turned out the lights, then opened them again in the morning.

speaker: None
text: Other than being unconscious, he appeared completely healthy.

speaker: None
text: He was in a coma, but didn't dream, apparently.

speaker: None
text: When people dream they exhibit characteristic eye movements and facial expressions.

speaker: None
text: Your heart rate goes up as you react to experiences in your dreams.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: But with the Nakata boy we couldn't detect any of these indicators.

speaker: None
text: His heart rate, breathing, and temperature were still slightly on the low side, but surprisingly stable.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: It might sound strange to put it this way, but it seemed like the real Nakata had gone off somewhere, leaving behind for a time the fleshly container, which in his absence kept all his bodily functions going at the minimum level needed to preserve itself.

speaker: None
text: The term "spirit projection" sprang to mind.

speaker: None
text: Are you familiar with it?

speaker: None
text: Japanese folk tales are full of this sort of thing, where the soul temporarily leaves the body and goes off a great distance to take care of some vital task and then returns to reunite with the body.

speaker: None
text: The sort of vengeful spirits that populate The Tale of Genji may be something similar.

speaker: None
text: The notion of the soul not just leaving the body at death but--assuming the will is strong enough--also being able to separate from the body of the living is probably an idea that took root in Japan in ancient times.

speaker: None
text: Of course there's no scientific proof of this, and I hesitate to even raise the idea.

speaker: None
text: The practical problem that faced us was how to wake this boy from his coma, and restore him to consciousness.

speaker: None
text: Struggling to find a reverse trigger to undo the hypnosis, we tried everything.

speaker: None
text: We brought his parents there, had them shout out his name.

speaker: None
text: We tried that for several days, but there was no reaction.

speaker: None
text: We tried every trick in the book as far as hypnosis goes--clapping our hands in different ways right in front of his face.

speaker: None
text: We played music he knew, read his schoolbooks aloud to him, let him catch a whiff of his favorite foods.

speaker: None
text: We even brought in his cat from home, one he was particularly fond of.

speaker: None
text: We used every method we could think of to bring him back to reality, but nothing worked.

speaker: None
text: About two weeks into this, when we'd run out of ideas and were exhausted and discouraged, the boy woke up on his own.

speaker: None
text: Not because of anything we'd done.

speaker: None
text: Without warning, as if the time for this had been decided in advance, he came to.

speaker: None
text: #NAME?

text: Nothing worth mentioning.

text: It was a day like any other.

text: At ten a. m. the nurse came to draw a blood sample.

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: Not much, and they changed the sheets right away.

speaker: None
text: That was about the only thing different that day.

speaker: None
text: The boy woke up about a half hour after that.

speaker: None
text: Out of the blue he sat up in bed, stretched, and looked around the room.

speaker: None
text: He had regained consciousness, and medically he was perfectly fine.

speaker: None

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: The place he lived in, his school, his parents' faces--it was all gone.

speaker: None
text: He couldn't read, and wasn't even aware this was Japan or the Earth.

speaker: None
text: He couldn't even fathom the concept of Japan or the Earth.

speaker: None
text: He'd returned to this world with his mind wiped clean.

speaker: None
text: The proverbial blank slate.

text: I can see the night sky through the tree branches.

speaker: None

speaker: None
