speaker: None
text: 12 October 19, 1972 Dear Professor, I'm sure you must be quite surprised to receive a letter from me, out of the blue.

speaker: None
text: Please forgive me for being so forward.

speaker: None
text: I imagine that you no longer remember my name, Professor, but I was at one time a teacher at a small elementary school in Yamanashi Prefecture.

speaker: None
text: When you read this, you may recall something about me.

speaker: None
text: I was the teacher in charge of the group of children on a field trip, the ones involved in the incident in which the children all lost consciousness.

speaker: None
text: Afterward, as you may remember, I had the opportunity to speak with you and your colleagues from the university in Tokyo several times when you visited our town with people from the military to investigate.

speaker: None
text: In the years following I've often seen your name mentioned prominently in the press, and I have followed your career and achievements with the deepest admiration.

speaker: None
text: At the same time, I have fond memories of when we met, especially your very businesslike, brisk way of speaking.

speaker: None
text: I feel blessed, too, to have been able to read several of your books.

speaker: None
text: I've always been impressed by your insights, and I find the worldview that runs through all of your publications very convincing--namely that as individuals each of us is extremely isolated, while at the same time we are all linked by a prototypical memory.

speaker: None
text: There have been times in my own life that I felt exactly this way.

speaker: None
text: From afar, then, I pray for your continued success.

speaker: None
text: After that incident I continued to teach at the same elementary school.

speaker: None
text: A few years ago, however, I unexpectedly fell ill, was hospitalized for a long spell in Kofu General Hospital, and, after some time, submitted my resignation.

speaker: None
text: For a year I was in and out of the hospital, but eventually I recovered, was discharged, and opened a small tutorial school in our town.

speaker: None
text: My students were the children of my former pupils.

speaker: None
text: It's a trite observation, perhaps, but it is true what they say--that time does fly--and I've found the passage of time to be incredibly swift.

speaker: None
text: During the war I lost both my husband and my father, then my mother as well in the confused period following the surrender.

speaker: None
text: With my husband off to war soon after we married, we never had any children, so I've been all alone in the world.

speaker: None
text: I wouldn't say my life has been happy, but it has been a great blessing to have been able to teach for so long and have the chance to work with so many children over the years.

speaker: None
text: I thank God for this opportunity.

speaker: None
text: If it hadn't been for teaching I don't think I'd have been able to survive.

speaker: None
text: I summoned up my courage today to write to you, Professor, because I've never been able to forget that incident in the woods in the fall of 1944.

speaker: None
text: Twenty-eight years have passed, but to me it's as fresh in my mind as if it took place yesterday.

speaker: None
text: Those memories are always with me, shadowing my every waking moment.

speaker: None
text: I've spent countless sleepless nights pondering it all, and it's even haunted my dreams.

speaker: None
text: It's as if the aftershocks of that incident affect every aspect of my life.

speaker: None
text: To give you an example, whenever I run across any of the children involved in the incident (half of whom still live here in town and are now in their mid-thirties) I always wonder what effects the incident had on them, and on myself.

speaker: None
text: Something as traumatic as that you'd think would have to have some lingering physical or psychological impact on all of us.

speaker: None
text: I can't believe otherwise.

speaker: None
text: But when it comes to pinpointing what sort of effects these were, and how great an impact it all had, I'm at a loss.

speaker: None
text: As you're well aware, Professor, the military kept news of this incident from reaching the public.

speaker: None
text: During the Occupation the American military conducted their own investigation behind closed doors.

speaker: None
text: The military's always the same, whether Japanese or American.

speaker: None
text: Even when censorship was lifted after the Occupation, no articles about the incident appeared in newspapers or magazines.

speaker: None
text: Which I suppose is understandable, since it had taken place years before and no one had died.

speaker: None
text: Because of this, most people are unaware that such an incident ever took place.

speaker: None
text: During the war there were so many horrific events, and millions of people lost their lives, so I don't suppose people would be very shocked by what happened in our little town.

speaker: None
text: Even here not many people remember what happened, and those who do don't appear willing to talk about it.

speaker: None
text: I'd say most people who recall the incident find it an unpleasant memory they'd prefer not to touch on.

speaker: None
text: Most things are forgotten over time.

speaker: None
text: Even the war itself, the life-and-death struggle people went through, is now like something from the distant past.

speaker: None
text: We're so caught up in our everyday lives that events of the past, like ancient stars that have burned out, are no longer in orbit around our minds.

speaker: None
text: There are just too many things we have to think about every day, too many new things we have to learn.

speaker: None
text: New styles, new information, new technology, new terminology...

speaker: None
text: But still, no matter how much time passes, no matter what takes place in the interim, there are some things we can never assign to oblivion, memories we can never rub away.

speaker: None
text: They remain with us forever, like a touchstone.

speaker: None
text: And for me, what happened in the woods that day is one of these.

speaker: None
text: I realize there's nothing I can do about it now, and I would certainly understand if you are puzzled about why I'm bringing this up at this late date.

speaker: None
text: But while I'm still alive there's something I have to get off my chest.

speaker: None
text: During the war, of course, we lived under strict censorship, and there were things we couldn't easily talk about.

speaker: None
text: When I met you, Professor, there were military officers with us and I couldn't speak freely.

speaker: None
text: Also, I didn't know anything about you then, or about your work, so I certainly didn't feel--as a young woman talking to a man she didn't know--I could be candid about any private matter.

speaker: None
text: Thus I kept several facts to myself.

speaker: None
text: In other words, in the official investigation I intentionally changed some of the facts about the incident.

speaker: None
text: And when, after the war, the American military interviewed me, I stuck to my story.

speaker: None
text: Out of fear and to keep up appearances, perhaps, I repeated the same lies I'd told you.

speaker: None
text: This may well have made it more difficult for you to investigate the incident, and may have somewhat skewed your conclusions.

speaker: None
text: No, I know it did.

speaker: None
text: This has bothered me for years, and I'm ashamed of what I did.

speaker: None
text: I hope this explains why I've written this long letter to you.

speaker: None
text: I realize you're a busy man and may not have time for this.

speaker: None
text: If so, please feel free to treat it all as the ramblings of an old woman and toss the letter away.

speaker: None
text: The thing is, I feel the need, while I'm still able, to confess all that really took place then, write it down, and pass it along to someone who should know.

speaker: None
text: I recovered from my illness, but you never know when there might be a relapse.

speaker: None
text: I hope you will take this into consideration.

speaker: None
text: The night before I took the children up into the hills, I had a dream about my husband, just before dawn.

speaker: None
text: He had been drafted and was off at war.

speaker: None
text: The dream was extremely realistic and sexually charged--one of those dreams that's so vivid it's hard to distinguish between dream and reality.

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: I had the children go off to gather their mushrooms, and was thinking we'd better make it a short trip and go back as soon as we could.

speaker: None

text: I kept a head count, and made sure none of them were out of my sight.

speaker: None
text: After a while, though, I noticed one little boy walking toward me with something in his hands.

text: It was the boy named Nakata--the same boy who didn't regain consciousness and was hospitalized.

speaker: None

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: I was wrong, please, please forgive me, I begged him.

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: They probably couldn't comprehend what had just taken place.

text: It was all too strange, too sudden.

text: I stood there for a while, holding Nakata tight in my arms, feeling like I wanted to die or disappear.

speaker: None
text: Just over the horizon the violence of war went on, with countless people dying.

speaker: None

speaker: None

speaker: None

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: I was angry, afraid, embarrassed--all of these rolled into one.

speaker: None
text: I cried quietly, without making a sound.

speaker: None
text: And that's when the children collapsed.

speaker: None
text: I wasn't about to tell the military people what had really happened.

speaker: None
text: It was wartime, and we had to keep up appearances.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: So I left out the part about my period starting, about Nakata finding the bloody towels, and me hitting him.

speaker: None
text: Again, I'm afraid this threw an obstacle in your path as you investigated the incident.

speaker: None
text: You can't imagine how relieved I am to finally get it off my chest.

speaker: None
text: Strangely enough, none of the children had any memory of the incident.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Nobody remembered the bloody towels or me beating Nakata.

speaker: None
text: Those memories had fallen away completely from their minds.

speaker: None
text: Later, soon after the incident, I was able to indirectly sound out each child and confirm that this was indeed the case.

speaker: None
text: Perhaps the mass coma had already started by then.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: I'd like to say a few things about young Nakata, as his former homeroom teacher.

speaker: None
text: What happened to him after the incident, I don't really know.

speaker: None
text: When I was interviewed after the war the American officer told me he'd been taken to a hospital in Tokyo and finally regained consciousness.

speaker: None
text: But he wouldn't tell me any details.

speaker: None
text: I imagine that you know more about this than I do, Professor.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Nakata was one of the five children evacuated to our town from Tokyo, and of the five he was the brightest and had the best grades.

speaker: None
text: He had very pleasant features and always dressed well.

speaker: None
text: He was a gentle boy and never butted in where he didn't belong.

speaker: None
text: Never once during class did he volunteer an answer, but when I called on him, he always gave the correct answer, and when I asked his opinion he'd give a logical reply.

speaker: None
text: He caught on right away, no matter what the subject.

speaker: None
text: Every class has a student like that, one who'll study what he needs to without supervision, who you know will one day attend a top college and get an excellent job.

speaker: None
text: A child who's innately capable.

speaker: None
text: But as his teacher I will say there were a couple of things about him that bothered me.

speaker: None
text: Every so often I felt a sense of resignation in him.

speaker: None
text: Even when he did well on difficult assignments, he never seemed happy.

speaker: None
text: He never struggled to succeed, never seemed to experience the pain of trial and error.

speaker: None
text: He never sighed or cracked a smile.

speaker: None
text: It was as if these were things he had to get through, so he just did them.

speaker: None
text: He handled whatever came his way efficiently--like a factory worker, screwdriver in hand, working on a conveyor belt, tightening a screw on each part that comes down the line.

speaker: None
text: I've never met his parents so I can't say anything for certain, but there had to be a problem back home.

speaker: None
text: I'd seen a number of cases like this.

speaker: None
text: Adults constantly raise the bar on smart children, precisely because they're able to handle it.

speaker: None
text: The children get overwhelmed by the tasks in front of them and gradually lose the sort of openness and sense of accomplishment they innately have.

speaker: None
text: When they're treated like that, children start to crawl inside a shell and keep everything inside.

speaker: None
text: It takes a lot of time and effort to get them to open up again.

speaker: None
text: Kids' hearts are malleable, but once they gel it's hard to get them back the way they were.

speaker: None

text: Kind of, I admit.

speaker: None
text: You can appreciate Schubert if you train yourself.

speaker: None
text: I was the same way when I first listened to him--it bored me silly.

speaker: None
text: It's only natural for someone your age.

speaker: None
text: In time you'll appreciate it.

speaker: None
text: People soon get tired of things that aren't boring, but not of what is boring.

speaker: None
text: Go figure.

speaker: None
text: For me, I might have the leisure to be bored, but not to grow tired of something.

speaker: None
text: Most people can't distinguish between the two.

speaker: None
text: You said you're an unusual person.

speaker: None
text: Do you mean because of the hemophilia?

speaker: None
text: That's part of it," he says, and gives this devilish sort of smile.

speaker: None
text: There's more to it than that.

speaker: None
text: Schubert's long Heavenly" sonata finishes, and we don't listen to any more music.

speaker: None
text: We fall silent, each of us filling in the silence with our own random thoughts.

speaker: None
text: I gaze vacantly at the passing signs.

speaker: None
text: At a junction we turn south and the road heads into the mountains, one long tunnel after another.

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima concentrates hard each time he passes another vehicle.

speaker: None
text: We go by a number of slow-moving trucks on the road, and every time there's this whooshing moan of air, like somebody's soul is being yanked out.

speaker: None
text: Occasionally I look back to make sure my backpack's still tied down okay.

speaker: Oshima
text: The place we're headed is deep in the mountains, not the most pleasant dwelling in the world, Oshima says.

speaker: None
text: I doubt you'll see anybody else while you're there.

speaker: None
text: There's no radio, TV, or phone.

speaker: None
text: Sure you don't mind?

speaker: None
text: I don't," I reply.

speaker: Oshima
text: You're used to being alone, Oshima comments.

speaker: None
text: I nod.

speaker: None
text: But solitude comes in different varieties.

speaker: None
text: What's waiting for you might be a little unexpected.

speaker: None
text: How so?

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima pushes up the bridge of his glasses.

speaker: None
text: I can't really say.

speaker: None
text: It might change, depending on you.

speaker: None
text: We get off the highway and start down a small regional roadway.

speaker: None
text: Along a side road near the exit there's a small town.

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima stops at a convenience store and buys almost more groceries than we can carry--vegetables and fruit, crackers, milk and mineral water, canned goods, bread, pouch-packed instant food, mostly things that don't require much cooking.

speaker: None
text: I start to take out my wallet, but he shakes his head and pays for it all.

speaker: None
text: Back in the sports car, we head down the road.

speaker: None
text: I'm holding the bags that wouldn't fit into the trunk.

speaker: None
text: Once we leave the little town everything is dark around us.

speaker: None
text: No houses, and only the occasional car, the road so narrow it's hard for two cars to pass each other.

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima flips on the high beams and races ahead, braking, accelerating, shifting from second to third and back.

speaker: None
text: His expression is fixed as he focuses on driving, lips tight, eyes riveted on a point up ahead in the darkness, right hand clutching the top of the wheel, left hand poised for action on the gearshift knob.

speaker: None
text: A sharp bluff appears on our left side.

speaker: None
text: It looks like there's a mountain stream down below.

speaker: None
text: The curves get sharper, the road more slippery, and a couple of times the rear end of the car spins, but I decide not to worry about it.

speaker: Oshima
text: As far as Oshima is concerned, having an accident here most likely isn't an option.

speaker: None
text: My watch shows a little before nine.

speaker: None
text: I crack open my window and let the cold air rush in.

speaker: None
text: Everything sounds different here.

speaker: None
text: We're in the mountains, heading in deeper.

speaker: None
text: I breathe a sigh of relief when the road finally cuts away from the bluffs and turns into a forest.

speaker: None
text: Trees magically soar above us.

speaker: None
text: Our headlights lick at the trunks, illuminating one after another.

speaker: None
text: We've left the paved road behind, the tires squirting out pebbles that ricochet against the bottom of the car.

speaker: None
text: The suspension dances up and down over the rough road.

speaker: None
text: There's no moon out, no stars.

speaker: None
text: A fine rain occasionally splashes against the windshield.

speaker: None
text: Do you come here a lot?

speaker: None
text: I ask.

speaker: None
text: I used to.

speaker: None
text: Now, with the job and all I can't come so often.

speaker: None
text: My older brother's a surfer and lives on the shore in Kochi.

speaker: None
text: He runs a surf shop there and makes surfboards.

speaker: None
text: He comes here sometimes.

speaker: None
text: Do you surf?

speaker: None
text: Never tried it," I tell him.

speaker: None
text: If you have the chance, you should have my brother teach you.

speaker: Oshima
text: He's very good," Oshima says.

speaker: None
text: If you meet him you'll see he's not at all like me.

speaker: None
text: He's big, tan, kind of quiet, not so sociable, and likes beer.

speaker: None
text: And wouldn't know Schubert from Wagner.

speaker: None
text: But we get along really well.

speaker: None
text: We continue down the road through thick woods, and finally turn off.

text: Oshima stops the car and, leaving the engine running, climbs out and unlocks a kind of wire fence and pushes it open.

speaker: None
text: We drive inside and proceed down another windy, bumpy road into a clearing where the road ends.

text: Oshima stops the car, sighs heavily, and brushes his hair back with both hands, then kills the engine and sets the parking brake.

speaker: None
text: The fan still hums, cooling off the overheated engine as steam rises from the hood, but with the engine off a heavy stillness falls over us.

speaker: None
text: I hear a small stream nearby, the faint sound of water.

speaker: None
text: High above us the wind rustles symbolically.

speaker: None
text: I open the door and step outside.

speaker: None
text: Patches of chill hang in the air.

speaker: None
text: I have on a yacht jacket over my T-shirt and zip it up to my neck.

speaker: None
text: There's a small building in front of us, a log cabin by the look of it, though it's too dark to see much.

speaker: None
text: Just a dark outline floating against the background of the forest.

text: The headlights still on, Oshima slowly approaches the cabin, flashlight in hand, walks up the porch steps, takes out a key, and unlocks the door.

speaker: None
text: He goes inside, strikes a match, and lights a lamp.

speaker: None
text: He then steps out onto the porch, holding the lamp, and announces, "Welcome to my house.

speaker: None
text: It all looks like a drawing in an old storybook.

speaker: None
text: I walk up the steps and go inside.

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima lights a larger lamp suspended from the ceiling.

speaker: None
text: The cabin consists of a single big, boxy room.

speaker: None
text: There's a small bed in the corner, a dining table and two wooden chairs, an old sofa, a hopelessly faded rug--a bunch of old furniture nobody wanted, it looks like, just thrown together.

speaker: None
text: There's a cinder block and board shelf crammed full of books, their covers worn like they've been read a lot.

speaker: None
text: There's also an old chest for storing clothes.

speaker: None
text: And a simple kitchen with a counter, a small gas stove, and a sink but no running water.

speaker: None
text: Instead, an aluminum pail I guess is for water.

speaker: None
text: A pan and kettle on a shelf, plus a frying pan hanging from the wall.

speaker: None
text: And in the middle of the room there's a black wood-burning stove.

speaker: None
text: My brother built this cabin almost all by himself.

speaker: None
text: He took the original rough lumberjack hut and remodeled it completely.

speaker: None
text: He's good with his hands.

speaker: None
text: I was still pretty little then and helped out a bit, making sure I didn't get cut or anything.

speaker: None
text: It's pretty primitive.

speaker: None
text: No electricity.

speaker: None
text: No running water.

speaker: None
text: No toilet.

speaker: None
text: The only modern convenience is the propane gas.

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima pours some mineral water into the kettle and sets it to boil.

speaker: None
text: My grandfather originally owned this mountain.

speaker: None
text: He was a pretty wealthy man in Kochi, with a lot of property.

speaker: None
text: He passed away ten years ago, and my brother and I inherited almost the entire mountain.

speaker: None
text: No other relatives wanted it.

speaker: None
text: It's too far off the beaten track, and not worth much.

speaker: None
text: If you were going to maintain it for harvesting trees, you'd have to hire people and it'd cost too much.

speaker: None
text: I open the curtain at the window.

speaker: None
text: All I can see is a wall of total darkness.

speaker: Oshima
text: When I was just about your age, Oshima says, dipping chamomile tea bags into a pot, "I used to come here a lot and live on my own.

speaker: None
text: Not see anybody else, not talk to anybody.

speaker: None
text: My brother almost forced me to.

speaker: None
text: Usually, with somebody who has a disease like mine, you wouldn't do that--too dangerous for them to be alone in some isolated spot.

speaker: None
text: But my brother didn't mind.

speaker: None
text: He leans back against the counter, waiting for the water to boil.

speaker: None
text: He wasn't trying to discipline me or anything, it's just what he believed I needed.

speaker: None
text: Looking back on it, I can see it was a good experience, something I did need.

speaker: None
text: I could read a lot, think things over.

speaker: None
text: To tell the truth, after a certain period I hardly went to school.

speaker: None
text: School and I had sort of a mutual hate relationship going.

speaker: None
text: I was different from everybody else.

speaker: None
text: Out of the kindness of their hearts they let me graduate from junior high, but after that I was on my own, basically.

speaker: None
text: Just like you.

speaker: None
text: Did I already tell you all this?

speaker: None
text: I shake my head.

speaker: None
text: Is that why you're being so nice to me?

speaker: None
text: That's part of it," he says, then pauses.

speaker: None
text: But that's not the whole reason.

text: Oshima passes me a cup of tea and sips at his own.

speaker: None
text: My nerves are tense after the long drive, and the chamomile is just what I need to calm down.

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima glances at his watch.

speaker: None
text: I'd better be going, so let me explain everything.

speaker: None
text: There's a nice stream nearby you can use for water.

speaker: None
text: It's spring fed so you can drink it as is.

speaker: None
text: Much better than these bottles of mineral water.

speaker: None
text: There's firewood stacked up in back so use the stove if you get cold.

speaker: None
text: It gets pretty chilly here.

speaker: None
text: I've even used it a few times in August.

speaker: None
text: You can use the stove for simple cooking.

speaker: None
text: If you need any other tools or anything, check the toolshed out back.

speaker: None
text: And feel free to wear any old clothes of my brother's you find in the dresser.

speaker: None
text: He doesn't care if somebody wears his things.

text: Oshima rests his hands on his hips and gives the cabin a once-over.

speaker: None
text: It's not some romantic getaway, that's for sure.

speaker: None
text: But for simple living, it'll do.

speaker: None
text: One thing I've got to warn you about--don't go very far into the woods.

speaker: None
text: The forest is really dense, and there's not a good path through it.

speaker: None
text: Always keep the cabin in sight.

speaker: None
text: It's easy to get lost if you go any farther, and it's hard to find your way back.

speaker: None
text: I had a terrible experience there once.

speaker: None
text: I was only a couple hundred yards from here but spent half the day going in circles.

speaker: None
text: You might think Japan's a small country, that there's no chance you could get lost in a forest.

speaker: None
text: But once you get lost in these woods, believe me, you stay lost.

speaker: None
text: I file that away for future reference.

speaker: None
text: And except for an emergency, I wouldn't come down off the mountain.

speaker: None
text: It's too far to any other houses.

speaker: None
text: Just wait here, and I'll be back in a couple of days to pick you up.

speaker: None
text: You have enough food to see you through.

text: By the way, do you have a cell phone?

text: I do," I tell him, pointing at my backpack.

text: Keep it in your pack.

speaker: None

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: 14 Nakata visited the vacant lot for several days.

speaker: None
text: One morning it rained heavily, so he spent the day doing simple woodworking in his room, but apart from that he spent his time seated in the weeds waiting for the missing tortoiseshell cat to show up, or the man in the strange hat.

speaker: None
text: But no luck.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: At the end of each day Nakata stopped by the home of the people who'd hired him and gave an update on his search--where he'd gone, what sort of information he'd managed to pick up.

speaker: None
text: The cat's owner would pay him twenty dollars, his going rate.

speaker: None
text: Nobody had ever officially set that fee, word just got around that there was a master catfinder in the neighborhood and somehow he settled on that daily rate.

speaker: None
text: People would always give him something extra besides the money, too--food, occasionally clothes.

speaker: None
text: And a bonus of eighty dollars once he actually tracked down the missing cat.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Nakata wasn't constantly being asked to search for missing cats, so the fees he accumulated each month didn't add up to much.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: The older of his younger brothers paid his utilities out of the inheritance Nakata's parents had left him--which wasn't very much to begin with--and he lived on his meager savings and a municipal monthly subsidy for the elderly handicapped.

speaker: None
text: He managed to get by on the subsidy alone, so he could spend his cat-finding fees as he wished, and for him it seemed like a substantial amount.

speaker: None
text: Sometimes, though, he couldn't come up with any idea of how to spend it, other than enjoying his favorite grilled eel.

speaker: None
text: Going to the bank or having a savings account at the post office involved filling out forms, so any leftover money he hid beneath the tatami in his room.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Being able to converse with cats was Nakata's little secret.

speaker: None
text: Only he and the cats knew about it.

speaker: None
text: People would think he was crazy if he mentioned it, so he never did.

speaker: None
text: Everybody knew he wasn't very bright, but being dumb and being crazy were different matters altogether.

speaker: None
text: Sometimes people would walk by when he was deep in conversation with a cat, but they never seemed to care.

speaker: None
text: It wasn't so unusual, after all, to see old folks talking to animals as if they were people.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: But if anyone did happen to comment on his abilities with cats and say something like, "Mr. Nakata, how are you able to know cats' habits so well?

speaker: None
text: It's almost like you can talk with them," he'd just smile and let it pass.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Nakata was always serious and well mannered, with a pleasant smile, and was a favorite among the housewives in the neighborhood.

speaker: None
text: His neat appearance also helped.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Poor though he was, Nakata enjoyed bathing and doing laundry, and the nearly brand-new clothes his clients often gave him only added to his clean-cut look.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Some of the clothes--a salmon pink Jack Nicklaus golf shirt, for instance--didn't exactly suit him, but Nakata didn't mind as long as they were neat and clean.

text: Nakata finally got some information about little Goma, he began.

text: A person named Kawamura said that a few days ago he saw a cat resembling Goma over in the empty lot, the one with the wall around it, over in the 2-chome District.

speaker: Goma
text: It's two big roads away from here, and he said the age, coat, and collar are all the same as Goma's.

text: Nakata decided to keep a lookout at the empty lot, so I take a lunch and sit there every day, morning till sunset.

text: No, don't worry about that--I have plenty of free time, so unless it's raining hard I don't mind at all.

speaker: None
text: But despite the shock to the girls, she didn't have the time to go around town looking for their cat.

speaker: None

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: I start to read and learn how this totally practical lieutenant colonel in the SS, with his metal-frame glasses and thinning hair, was, soon after the war started, assigned by Nazi headquarters to design a "final solution" for the Jews--extermination, that is--and how he investigated the best ways of actually carrying this out.

speaker: None
text: Apparently it barely crossed his mind to question the morality of what he was doing.

speaker: None
text: All he cared about was how best, in the shortest period of time and for the lowest possible cost, to dispose of the Jews.

speaker: None
text: And we're talking about eleven million Jews he figured needed to be eliminated in Europe.

speaker: None
text: Eichmann studied how many Jews could be packed into each railroad car, what percentage would die of "natural" causes while being transported, the minimal number of people needed to keep this operation going.

speaker: None
text: The cheapest method of disposing of the dead bodies--burning, or burying, or dissolving them.

speaker: None

text: 21 SCULPTOR KOICHI TAMURA STABBED TO DEATH Found in Study, Floor a Sea of Blood The world-renowned sculptor Koichi Tamura was found dead on the afternoon of the 30th in the study in his home in Nogata, Nakano Ward.

speaker: None
text: The body was discovered by a female housekeeper.

speaker: None
text: Mr. Tamura was found facedown, nude, covered in blood.

speaker: None
text: There were signs of a struggle and the death is being treated as a homicide.

speaker: None
text: The weapon used was a knife from the kitchen discovered beside the body.

speaker: None
text: The police estimate the time of death as the evening of the 28th, and since Mr. Tamura lived alone the body was only discovered two days later.

speaker: None
text: Mr. Tamura suffered several deep stab wounds to the chest from the sharp steak knife, and it is believed he died almost instantly from massive loss of blood from injuries to the heart and lungs.

speaker: None
text: Several ribs were also broken from what appears to be massive blunt force.

speaker: None
text: The police have not announced having found any fingerprints or anything left behind at the scene.

speaker: None
text: It also appears that there were no witnesses to the crime.

speaker: None
text: Since the house was undisturbed, and valuables and a wallet near the scene were not taken, police view the crime as a personal vendetta.

speaker: None
text: Mr. Tamura's home is in a quiet residential neighborhood, but no one heard anything at the time of the murder, and neighbors were shocked at the news.

speaker: None
text: Mr. Tamura had little to do with his neighbors and lived quietly, and no one noticed anything out of the ordinary around the time of the incident.

speaker: None
text: Mr. Tamura lived with his son (15), but according to the housekeeper the son hasn't been seen in some ten days.

speaker: None
text: The son has also been absent from his junior high and police are tracing his whereabouts.

speaker: None
text: In addition to his residence, Mr. Tamura had an office and studio in Musashino City, and according to his secretary, until the day before the murder he was working on a new piece of sculpture as usual.

speaker: None
text: On the day of the incident, there was a matter she had to contact him about, but every time she phoned his residence she got his message machine.

speaker: None
text: Mr. Tamura was born in Kokubunji, Tokyo.

speaker: None
text: He entered the Dept.

speaker: None
text: of Sculpture at Tokyo Arts Institute, and while still a student completed many innovative pieces that became the talk of the art world.

speaker: None
text: His chief theme was the human subconscious, and his sculptures, which were in a unique style that challenged the conventional, were internationally acclaimed.

speaker: None
text: His best known work was his major "Labyrinth" series, which explored, through an uninhibited expression of the imagination, the beauty and inspiration found in the meandering contours of labyrinths.

speaker: None
text: He was at present a visiting professor at an art institute, and two years ago, at the exhibition of his work at the Museum of Modern Art in New York....

speaker: None

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: Since then, he couldn't recall seeing the sea even once.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: After the strange incident in the hills of Yamanashi, Nakata went back to school in Tokyo.

speaker: None
text: He'd regained consciousness and physically was fine, but his memory had been wiped clean, and he never regained the ability to read and write.

speaker: None
text: He couldn't read his school textbooks, and couldn't take any tests.

speaker: None
text: All the knowledge he'd gained up till then had vanished, as had the ability, to a great extent, to think in abstract terms.

speaker: None
text: Still, they let him graduate.

speaker: None
text: He couldn't follow what was being taught, and instead sat quietly in a corner of the classroom.

speaker: None
text: When the teacher told him to do something, he followed her instructions to the letter.

speaker: None
text: He didn't bother anyone, so teachers tended to forget he was even there.

speaker: None
text: He was more like a guest sitting in than a burden.

speaker: None
text: People soon forgot that until the accident he'd always gotten straight As.

speaker: None
text: But now the school activities and events took place without him.

speaker: None
text: He didn't make any friends.

speaker: None
text: None of this bothered him, though.

speaker: None
text: Being left alone meant he could be lost in his own little world.

speaker: None
text: What absorbed him the most at school was taking care of the rabbits and goats they raised there, tending the flower beds outside and cleaning the classrooms.

speaker: None
text: A constant smile on his face, he never tired of these chores.

speaker: None
text: He was essentially forgotten about at home, too.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Once they learned that their eldest son couldn't read anymore or follow along with his lessons, Nakata's parents-- totally focused on their children's education--ignored him and turned their attention to his younger brothers.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: It was impossible for Nakata to go on to public junior high, so once he graduated from elementary school he was sent to live with relatives in Nagano Prefecture, in his mother's hometown.

speaker: None
text: There he attended agriculture school.

speaker: None
text: Since he still couldn't read he had a hard time with his schoolwork, but he loved working in the fields.

speaker: None
text: He might even have become a farmer, if his classmates hadn't tormented him so much.

speaker: None
text: They enjoyed beating up this outsider, this city kid, so much.

speaker: None
text: His injuries became so severe (one cauliflower ear included) that his grandparents pulled him out of school and kept him at home to help out around the house.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Nakata was a quiet, obedient child, and his grandparents loved him very much.

speaker: None
text: It was about this time that he discovered he could speak with cats.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: His grandparents had a few cats around the house, and Nakata became good friends with them.

speaker: None
text: At first he was able to speak only a few words, but he knuckled down like he was trying to master a foreign language and before long was able to carry on extended conversations.

speaker: None
text: Whenever he was free he liked to sit on the porch and talk with the cats.

speaker: None
text: For their part, the cats taught him a lot about nature and the world around him.

speaker: None
text: Actually almost all the basic knowledge he had about the world and how it worked he learned from his feline friends.

speaker: None
text: At fifteen he was sent to a nearby furniture company to learn woodworking.

speaker: None
text: It was less a factory than a small woodworking shop making folkcraft-type furniture.

speaker: None
text: Chairs, tables, and chests made there were shipped to Tokyo.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Nakata grew to love woodworking.

speaker: None
text: His boss took a great liking to him, for he was skilled with his hands, never skipped any small details, didn't talk much, and never, ever complained.

speaker: None
text: Reading a blueprint and adding figures weren't his forte, but aside from these tasks he did well at everything he set his hand to.

speaker: None
text: Once he got the manufacturing steps in his mind he could repeat them endlessly, tirelessly.

speaker: None
text: After a two-year apprenticeship he was given full-time employment.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Nakata worked there until he was past fifty, never once having an accident or calling in sick.

speaker: None
text: He didn't drink or smoke, didn't stay up late or overeat.

speaker: None
text: He never watched TV, and listened to the radio only for the morning exercise program.

speaker: None
text: Day after day he just made furniture.

speaker: None
text: His grandparents eventually passed away, as did his parents.

speaker: None
text: Everybody liked him, though he didn't make any close friends.

speaker: None
text: Perhaps that was only to be expected.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: When most people tried talking to Nakata, ten minutes was all it took for them to run out of things to say.

speaker: None
text: Still, he never felt lonely or unhappy.

speaker: None
text: He never felt sexual desire, or even wanted to be with anyone.

speaker: None
text: He understood he was different from other people.

speaker: None
text: Though no one else noticed this, he thought his shadow on the ground was paler, lighter, than that of other people.

speaker: None
text: The only ones who really understood him were the cats.

speaker: None
text: On days off he'd sit on a park bench and spend the whole day chatting with them.

speaker: None
text: Strangely enough, with cats he never ran out of things to talk about.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: The owner of the furniture company passed away when Nakata was fifty-two, and the woodworking shop was closed soon afterward.

speaker: None
text: That kind of gloomy, dark, traditional furniture didn't sell as well as it used to.

speaker: None
text: The craftsmen were all getting on in years, and no young people were interested in learning the trade.

speaker: None
text: The shop itself, originally in the middle of a field, was now surrounded by newly built homes, and complaints started to come in about both the noise and the smoke when they burned wood shavings.

speaker: None
text: The owner's son, who worked in town for an accounting firm, had no interest in taking over the business, so as soon as his father passed away he sold the property to a real estate developer.

speaker: None
text: For his part, the developer tore down the shop, had the land graded, and sold it to an apartment complex developer, who constructed a sixstory condominium on the property.

speaker: None
text: Every single apartment in the condo sold out on the first day they were put on sale.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: That's how Nakata lost his job.

speaker: None
text: The company had some outstanding loans to pay off, so he received only a pittance as retirement pay.

speaker: None
text: Afterward he couldn't find another job.

speaker: None
text: Who was going to hire an illiterate man in his fifties whose only skill was crafting antique furniture nobody wanted anymore?

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Nakata had worked steadily for thirty-seven years at the plant without taking a single day of leave, so he did have a fair amount of money in his savings account at the local post office.

speaker: None
text: He generally spent very little on himself, so even without finding another job he should have been able to have a comfortable old age on his savings.

speaker: None
text: Since he couldn't read or write, a cousin of his who worked at city hall managed his account for him.

speaker: None
text: Though kind enough, this cousin wasn't so quick on the uptake and was tricked into investing in a condominium at a ski resort by an unscrupulous real estate broker and ended up deeply in debt.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Around the same time that Nakata lost his job, this cousin disappeared with his entire family to escape his creditors.

speaker: None
text: Some yakuza-type loan sharks were after him, apparently.

speaker: None
text: Nobody knew where this family was, or even if they were still alive.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: When Nakata had an acquaintance go with him to the post office to check on the balance in his account, he found out that only a few hundred dollars were left.

speaker: None
text: His retirement pay, which had been deposited directly into the account, had also vanished.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: One could only say that Nakata was extremely unlucky--losing his job and finding himself penniless.

speaker: None
text: His relatives were sympathetic, but they'd been asked to put up collateral and likewise lost everything they'd invested with the cousin.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: So none of them had the resources to help Nakata in his time of need.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: In the end the older of Nakata's two younger brothers in Tokyo decided to look after him for the time being.

speaker: None
text: He owned a small apartment building in Nakano that catered to single men--this was part of his inheritance from his parents--and he offered one of the units to his older brother.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: He also looked after the money his parents had willed to Nakata--not a great amount--and arranged for him to receive a subsidy for the mentally challenged from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government.

speaker: None
text: That was the extent of the brother's "care.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Despite his illiteracy, Nakata was able to take care of his daily needs by himself, and as long as his rent was covered he was able to manage.

speaker: None
text: His two brothers had very little contact with him.

speaker: None
text: They saw him a few times when he first moved back to Tokyo, but that was it.

speaker: None
text: They had lived apart for over thirty years, and their lifestyles were too different.

speaker: None
text: Neither brother had any particular feelings toward him, and in any case they were too busy with their own careers to take care of a retarded sibling.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: But this cold treatment by his relatives didn't faze Nakata.

speaker: None
text: He was used to being alone and actually tensed up if people went out of their way to be nice to him.

speaker: None
text: He wasn't angry, either, that his cousin had squandered his life savings.

speaker: None
text: Naturally he understood it was too bad it happened, but he wasn't disappointed by the whole affair.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Nakata had no idea what a resort condo was, or what "investing" meant, nor did he understand what taking out a "loan" involved.

speaker: None
text: He lived in a world circumscribed by a very limited vocabulary.

speaker: None
text: Only amounts up to fifty dollars or so had any meaning to him.

speaker: None
text: Anything above that--a thousand dollars, ten thousand, a hundred thousand--was all the same to him.

speaker: None
text: A lot of money, that's all it meant.

speaker: None
text: He might have savings, but he'd never seen it.

speaker: None
text: They just told him, "This is how much you have in your account," and told him an amount, which to him was an abstract concept.

speaker: None
text: So when it all vanished he never had the sense that he'd actually lost something real.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: So Nakata lived a contented life in the small apartment his brother provided, receiving his monthly subsidy, using his special bus pass, going to the local park to chat with the cats.

speaker: None
text: This little corner of Nakano became his new world.

speaker: None
text: Just like dogs and cats, he marked off his territory, a boundary line beyond which, except in unusual circumstances, he never ventured.

speaker: None
text: As long as he stayed there he felt safe and content.

speaker: None
text: No dissatisfactions, no anger at anything.

speaker: None
text: No feelings of loneliness, anxieties about the future, or worries that his life was difficult or inconvenient.

speaker: None
text: Day after day, for more than ten years, this was his life, leisurely enjoying whatever came along.

speaker: Johnnie Walker
text: Until the day that Johnnie Walker showed up.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Nakata hadn't seen the sea in years, for there was no sea in Nagano Prefecture, or in Nakano Ward.

speaker: None
text: Now for the first time, he realized that he'd lost the sea for so long.

speaker: None
text: He hadn't even thought about it all those many years.

speaker: None
text: He nodded several times to himself, confirming this fact.

speaker: None
text: He took off his hat, rubbed his closely-cropped head with his palm, put his hat back on, and gazed out at the sea.

speaker: None
text: This is the extent of his knowledge of the sea: it was very big, it was salty, and fish lived there.

speaker: None
text: He sat there on the bench, breathing in the scent of the sea, watching seagulls circle overhead, gazing at ships anchored far offshore.

speaker: None

text: 45 As advertised, the path from the "entrance" on is hard to follow.

speaker: None
text: Actually, it's pretty much given up on trying to be a path.

speaker: None
text: The farther we go, the deeper and more enormous the forest gets.

speaker: None
text: The slope gets a whole lot steeper, the ground more overgrown with bushes and undergrowth.

speaker: None
text: The sky has just about disappeared, and it's so dim that it seems like twilight.

speaker: None
text: Thick spiderwebs loom up all over the place, and the air's thick with the smell of plants.

speaker: None
text: The silence gets even deeper, like the forest is trying to reject this invasion of its territory by human beings.

speaker: None
text: The soldiers, rifles slung across their backs, seem oblivious as they easily cut through openings in the thick foliage.

speaker: None
text: They're amazingly fast as they slip past the low-hanging branches, clamber up rocks, leap over hollows, neatly avoiding all the thorns.

speaker: None
text: I scramble to keep up and not lose sight of them as they forge on ahead.

speaker: None
text: They never check to see if I'm still there.

speaker: None
text: It's like they're testing me, to see how much I can handle.

speaker: None
text: I don't know why, but it almost feels like they're angry with me.

speaker: None
text: They don't say a word, not just to me but to each other.

speaker: None
text: They're totally focused on walking.

speaker: None
text: Without a word between them, they take turns in the lead.

speaker: None
text: The black barrels of the rifles on their backs swing back and forth in front of me, as regular as a metronome.

speaker: None
text: The whole thing starts to get hypnotic after a while.

speaker: None
text: My mind starts to wander, like it's slipping on ice, to somewhere else.

speaker: None
text: But I still have to focus on keeping up with their relentless pace, so I march on, the sweat pouring off me now.

speaker: None
text: We going too fast for you?

speaker: None
text: the brawny soldier finally turns around and asks.

speaker: None
text: He's not out of breath at all.

speaker: None
text: No, I'm fine, I tell him.

speaker: None
text: I'm hanging in there.

speaker: None
text: You're young, and look like you're in good shape," the tall one comments without looking around.

speaker: None
text: We know this path real well, so sometimes we speed up too much, the brawny one explains.

speaker: None
text: So tell me if we're going too fast.

speaker: None
text: Don't be shy, okay?

speaker: None
text: Just say the word and we'll slow down.

speaker: None
text: But understand we don't want to go any slower than we have to.

speaker: None
text: You know what I'm saying?

speaker: None
text: I'll let you know if I can't keep up," I tell him, forcing myself not to breathe too hard, so they won't have any idea how tired this is making me.

speaker: None
text: Do we have far to go?

text: No, not really," the tall one answers.

speaker: None
text: We're almost there, the other one adds.

speaker: None
text: I'm not sure I really believe him.

speaker: None
text: Like they said, time's not much of a factor here.

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: It seems like they've finished testing me.

text: Are there any poisonous snakes in this forest?

text: I haven't seen any, but there might be some.

text: What we're trying to say," the tall one adds casually, "is that the forest isn't out to harm you.

text: But if you just stab without twisting, then your enemy can jump up and rip your guts to shreds.

text: Guts.

text: My head's full of all kinds of thoughts, all intertwined and tangled.

text: I can't tell the difference between one thing and another.

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: Nobody's out on the roads.

speaker: None
text: The buildings are all expressionless, built less for beauty than to withstand the elements.

speaker: None
text: The place is too small to be called a town.

text: There aren't any shops as far as I can tell.

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: It's like a bunch of buildings, all the same size and shape, just happened to come together to make up a little community.

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: Like with the forest all around there's no need for any extra plants or trees.

speaker: None
text: A faint breeze is cutting through the woods, making the leaves of the trees around me tremble.

speaker: None
text: That anonymous rustling forms ripples on the folds of my mind.

text: Those ripples seem to be a sign, a signal of some sort, but it's like a foreign language I can't decipher.

speaker: None
text: I give up, open my eyes, and gaze out again at this brand-new world before me.

speaker: None

text: For the time being.

speaker: None
text: Not a factor at all.

text: The pots, plates, and various utensils in the kitchen aren't new, but it's clear they've been well cared for and are all clean.

speaker: None
text: It's a famous scene.

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: Just like when I first saw it, I wonder how things would've turned out if I'd had someone like Maria with me.

speaker: None

speaker: None

text: Or is it a videotape being played somewhere and shown on this set?

text: I'm thirsty, so I go to the kitchen and drink some milk from the jug.

speaker: None

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: That's another one of the few movies from my childhood.

speaker: None

text: The air in the room had that special solidity found only in a room with a corpse in it.

text: he said to Nakata, who naturally didn't have an opinion one way or the other.

text: Twilight came on, the room by degrees turning dark, but he didn't even get up to switch on the light.

text: He felt completely drained, and once ensconced on the sofa couldn't rouse himself enough to get up.

speaker: None
text: Time came slowly and passed slowly, so leisurely that at times he could swear it had stealthily doubled back on itself.

text: When his own grandfather died, he thought, it was hard, but nothing like this.

text: Always leaping before I look, always screwing things up.

speaker: None
text: You're as antsy as a cat in heat, my grandpa used to tell me.

speaker: None
text: But now I've got to sit tight and wait.

speaker: None
text: Gut it out!

speaker: None
text: Everything was quiet except for the groan of the AC going full blast next door.

speaker: None
text: The clock showed nine, then ten, but nothing happened.

speaker: None
text: Time passed, the night grew deeper, nothing else.

speaker: Hoshino
text: Hoshino dragged his blankets into the living room, lay down on the sofa, and pulled them over him.

speaker: None
text: He figured that it was better, even asleep, to be near the stone in case something happened.

speaker: None
text: He turned off the light and shut his eyes.

speaker: None
text: Hey, stone!

speaker: None
text: I'm going to sleep now," he called out.

speaker: None
text: We'll talk again tomorrow.

speaker: None
text: It's been a long day, and I need some shut-eye.

speaker: None
text: Man, he thought, was that an understatement.

speaker: None
text: Long did not begin to describe it.

text: Hey, Gramps!

speaker: None
text: he called out more loudly.

text: Mr. Nakata?

speaker: None
text: You hear me?

speaker: None
text: No reply.

speaker: Hoshino
text: Hoshino sighed, closed his eyes, adjusted his pillow, and fell asleep.

speaker: None
text: He slept the whole night without a break, without a single dream.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: In the next room, Nakata slept his own deep, dreamless, stone-hard sleep.

speaker: Hoshino
text: As soon as he got up, just past seven the next morning, Hoshino went right in to check on Nakata.

speaker: None
text: As before, the AC was roaring full blast, blowing cold air into the room.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: And in the midst of that chilled room, Nakata was still dead.

speaker: None
text: Compared to the night before, death seemed to have a tighter grip on him.

speaker: None
text: His skin had grown ashen, his closed eyes more fixed and solemn.

speaker: Hoshino
text: He wasn't about to come back to life, suddenly sit up, and say, My apologies, Mr. Hoshino.

speaker: Satoru Nakata
text: Nakata just fell asleep.

speaker: None
text: I'm sorry.

text: No need to worry, I'll take it from here--and then deal with the stone.

speaker: None
text: That was never going to happen.

speaker: Hoshino
text: Nakata's checked out for good, Hoshino thought, and that's a fact.

speaker: None
text: He started shivering from the cold, so he stepped out and shut the door, then went into the kitchen, brewed some coffee in the coffeemaker and drank two cups, made some toast and ate it with butter and jam.

speaker: None
text: After eating he sat in the kitchen, smoked a couple of cigarettes, and gazed out the window.

speaker: None
text: The clouds had blown away sometime during the night, leaving an unbroken sunny summer sky.

speaker: None
text: The stone was in its customary spot next to the sofa.

speaker: None
text: It didn't sleep a wink, didn't wake up, just crouched there, unmoving, the entire night.

speaker: None
text: He tried picking it up and easily lifted it.

speaker: Hoshino
text: Hey there, Hoshino said in a cheerful voice, "it's me.

speaker: Hoshino
text: Your old pal Hoshino, remember?

speaker: None
text: Looks like it's just you and me today.

text: The stone was--not unexpectedly--speechless.

speaker: None
text: Ah, that's okay.

speaker: None
text: Doesn't matter if you don't remember.

speaker: None
text: We have lots of time to get to know each other--no need to rush.

speaker: None
text: He sat down beside the stone, started rubbing it, and wondered what sort of things you might talk about with a stone.

speaker: None
text: Having a conversation with a stone was a first and he couldn't think of any appropriate topics.

speaker: None
text: Best to avoid anything difficult this early in the morning, he figured.

speaker: None
text: The day was long, and whatever popped into his head would be fine.

speaker: None
text: He gave it some thought and chose a favorite subject: girls.

speaker: None
text: He reviewed each and every girl he'd ever slept with.

speaker: None
text: If he stuck to the ones whose names he remembered, it didn't add up to all that many.

speaker: None
text: He counted them off on his fingers.

speaker: None
text: Six, all told.

speaker: None
text: If I add the ones whose names I don't know, he thought, there'd be a lot more, but we'll put those on hold.

speaker: None
text: I guess it's pretty pointless talking to a stone about girls I've slept with, he said.

speaker: None
text: And I suppose you aren't exactly thrilled to hear all about my exploits first thing in the morning.

speaker: None
text: But I can't think of anything else, okay?

speaker: None
text: Who knows, maybe some lighter topic'll do you some good for a change.

speaker: None
text: FYI and all that.

speaker: Hoshino
text: Hoshino related some episodes in as much detail as he could recall.

speaker: None
text: The first was when he was in high school, back when he was into motorcycles and getting into trouble.

speaker: None
text: The girl was three years older than him and worked in a little bar in Gifu City.

speaker: None
text: They pretty much lived together for a while.

speaker: None
text: The girl was serious about the relationship, said she couldn't live without him.

speaker: None
text: She phoned my parents, he remembered, but they were none too happy about it, and the whole thing was getting too intense, so once I graduated from high school I joined the Self-Defense Force.

speaker: None
text: Right after I joined up I got stationed at a base in Yamanashi Prefecture, and the relationship fizzled out.

speaker: None
text: I never saw her again.

speaker: Hoshino
text: I guess lazy's my middle name, Hoshino explained to the stone.

speaker: None
text: And when things get sticky I tend to head for the door.

speaker: None
text: Not to brag or anything, but I'm pretty quick on my feet.

speaker: None
text: I've never followed anything to the bitter end.

speaker: None
text: Which is sort of a problem, I suppose.

speaker: None
text: The second girl he met near the base in Yamanashi.

speaker: None
text: He was off duty one day and helped her fix a flat on her Suzuki Alto.

speaker: None
text: She was a year older than him and attending nursing school.

speaker: Hoshino
text: She was a nice kid, Hoshino said to the stone.

speaker: None
text: Big breasts, a very warm person.

speaker: None
text: And man, did she like to get it on!

speaker: None
text: I was only nineteen, and we used to spend every day between the sheets.

speaker: None
text: Problem was, she was jealous like you wouldn't believe.

speaker: None
text: If I didn't see her on my days off she'd give me the third degree, ask where I went, what I did, who I was with.

speaker: None
text: I told her the truth, but that didn't satisfy her.

speaker: None
text: That's why we broke up.

speaker: None
text: We were together for about a year, I guess....

speaker: None
text: I don't know how you are, but I can't stand anyone getting on my case.

speaker: None
text: I feel like I can't breathe, and it makes me depressed.

speaker: None
text: So I ran away.

speaker: None
text: The cool thing about the SDF is you can always hole up on base till the whole thing blows over.

speaker: None
text: And there's nothing anybody can do about it.

speaker: None
text: If you want to dump a girl with no problems, going into the SDF's your ticket.

speaker: None
text: Good thing to remember.

speaker: None
text: But it's not all roses--not with digging foxholes and piling up sandbags and crap.

speaker: Hoshino
text: The more he talked, the more Hoshino realized how pointless his life had been.

speaker: None
text: Four of the six girls he'd gone out with had been nice.

speaker: None
text: (The other two, if you looked at it objectively, had personality problems, he decided.

speaker: None
text: ) Most of them had treated him pretty well.

speaker: None
text: No drop-dead beauties among them, though each was cute in her own way, and let him have sex whenever he felt like it.

speaker: None
text: Never complained if he skipped foreplay and went straight to the main course.

speaker: None
text: They fixed meals for him on his days off, bought him presents on his birthday, lent him money when he was a little short before payday--not that he ever remembered paying them back--and they never demanded anything in return.

speaker: None
text: All this, and I was an ungrateful bastard, he concluded.

speaker: None
text: I took everything for granted.

speaker: None
text: To his credit, he'd never cheated on any of them.

speaker: None
text: But let them complain a little, try to win an argument, show a bit of jealousy, urge him to save some money, get a little overwrought, or express even a hint of worry about the future, and he was out of there.

speaker: None
text: He always figured the most important thing about girls was to avoid any sticky situations, so all it took was one tiny wave to rock the boat and he was gone.

speaker: None
text: He'd find a new girl and start over.

speaker: None
text: He was sure most people did the same.

speaker: None
text: If I were a girl, he said to the stone, "and was going out with a self-centered bastard like me, I'd blow my stack.

speaker: None
text: I'm sure of it, now that I look back on it.

speaker: None
text: I don't know how they all put up with me for so long.

speaker: None
text: It's amazing.

speaker: None
text: He lit a Marlboro and, slowly exhaling smoke, rubbed the stone with one hand.

speaker: None
text: Am I right or what?

speaker: None
text: I'm not so good-looking, no great shakes in bed.

speaker: None
text: Don't have much money.

speaker: None
text: Not such a great personality, not too bright.

speaker: None
text: A lot of negatives here.

speaker: None
text: Son of a poor farmer from the sticks, a no-good ex-soldier-turned-truck-driver.

speaker: None
text: When I think back on it, though, I was really lucky when it came to girls.

speaker: None
text: I wasn't very popular, but I always had a girlfriend.

speaker: None
text: Someone who let me sleep with her, who fed me, lent me money.

speaker: None
text: But you know something?

speaker: None
text: Good things don't last forever.

speaker: None
text: I feel that more and more as time goes by.

speaker: Hoshino
text: It's like somebody's saying, Hey, Hoshino, someday you're gonna have to pay up.

speaker: None
text: He rubbed the stone while relating his amorous adventures.

speaker: None
text: He'd gotten so used to rubbing it that he didn't want to stop.

speaker: None
text: At noon a school chime rang out, and he went to the kitchen to make a bowl of udon, adding some scallions along with a raw egg.

speaker: None
text: After lunch he listened again to the Archduke Trio.

speaker: None
text: Hey, stone, he called out right after the first movement ended.

speaker: None
text: Pretty nice music, huh?

speaker: None
text: Really makes you feel like your heart's opening up, don't you think?

speaker: None
text: The stone was silent.

speaker: None
text: He had no idea if the stone was listening, to the music or to him, but he forged ahead anyway.

speaker: None
text: Like I was saying this morning, I've done some awful things in my life.

speaker: None
text: I was pretty self-centered.

speaker: None
text: And it's too late to erase it all now, you know?

speaker: Hoshino
text: But when I listen to this music it's like Beethoven's right here talking to me, telling me something like, It's okay, Hoshino, don't worry about it.

speaker: None

speaker: None
text: I've done some pretty awful things in my life too.

speaker: None

text: You just got to hang in there.

text: Beethoven being the guy he was, he's not about to say anything like that.

speaker: None
text: But I'm still picking up that vibe from his music, like that's what it's saying to me.

text: When he looked outside at two, a fat black cat was sitting on the railing on the veranda, gazing in at the apartment.

text: Bored, Hoshino opened the window and called out, "Hey there, kitty.

text: Yes, indeed, it is a fine day, Mr. Hoshino," the cat replied.
