text: Gimme a break, Hoshino said, shaking his head.

speaker: None
text: The Boy Named Crow The boy named Crow flew in large, languid circles above the forest.

speaker: None
text: After inscribing one, he'd fly off to another spot and carefully begin another, identical circle, each invisible circle following another in the air only to vanish.

speaker: None
text: Like a reconnaissance plane, he scanned the forest below him, looking for someone he couldn't seem to locate.

speaker: None
text: Like a huge ocean, the forest undulated beneath him and spread to the horizon in a thick, anonymous cloak of interlaced branches.

speaker: None
text: The sky was covered with gray clouds, and there was neither wind nor sunlight.

speaker: None
text: At this point the boy named Crow had to be the loneliest bird in the world, but he was too busy to think about that now.

speaker: None
text: He finally spotted an opening in the sea of trees below and shot straight down through it to an open piece of ground.

speaker: None
text: The light shone on a small patch of ground that was marked with grass.

speaker: None
text: In one corner of the clearing was a large round rock and a man in a bright red sweat suit and a black silk hat was sitting on it.

speaker: None
text: He wore thick-soled hiking boots, and a khaki-colored bag lay on the ground beside him.

speaker: None
text: A strange getup, though the boy named Crow didn't mind.

speaker: None
text: This was who he was after.

speaker: None
text: What the man had on was of little consequence.

speaker: None
text: The man looked up at the sudden flapping of wings and saw Crow land on a large branch.

speaker: None
text: Hey, he said cheerfully.

speaker: None
text: The boy named Crow didn't make any reply.

speaker: None
text: Resting on the branch, he gazed, unblinking, expressionless, at the man.

speaker: None
text: Occasionally he'd incline his head to one side.

speaker: None
text: I know who you are, the man said.

speaker: None
text: He doffed his hat and put it back on.

speaker: None
text: I had a feeling you'd be coming here before long.

speaker: None
text: He cleared his throat, frowned, and spat on the ground, then stamped the spit into the dirt with his boot.

speaker: None
text: I was just resting, and feeling a bit bored with no one to talk to.

speaker: None
text: How about coming over here?

speaker: None
text: We can have a nice little talk.

speaker: None
text: What do you say?

speaker: None
text: I've never seen you before, but that doesn't mean we're total strangers.

speaker: None
text: The boy named Crow kept his mouth shut, holding his wings close in against himself.

speaker: None
text: The man in the silk hat lightly shook his head.

speaker: None
text: Ah, I see.

speaker: None
text: You can't speak, can you?

speaker: None
text: No matter.

speaker: None
text: I'll do the talking, if you don't mind.

speaker: None
text: I know what you're going to do, even if you don't say a word.

speaker: None
text: You don't want me to go any further, do you?

speaker: None
text: It's so obvious I can predict what'll happen.

speaker: None
text: You don't want me to go any further, but that's exactly what I want to do.

speaker: None
text: Because it's a golden opportunity I can't let slip through my fingers--a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

speaker: None
text: He gave the ankle of his hiking boots a good slap.

speaker: None
text: To leap to the conclusion here, you won't be able to stop me.

speaker: None
text: You aren't qualified.

speaker: None
text: Let's say I play my flute, what's going to happen?

speaker: None
text: You won't be able to come any closer to me.

speaker: None
text: That's the power of my flute.

speaker: None
text: You might not know this, but it's a unique kind of flute, not just some ordinary, everyday instrument.

speaker: None
text: And actually I've got quite a few here in my bag.

speaker: None
text: The man reached out and carefully patted the bag, then looked up again at the boy named Crow perched on his branch.

speaker: None
text: I made this flute out of the souls of cats I've collected.

speaker: None
text: Cut out the souls of cats while they were still alive and made them into this flute.

speaker: None
text: I felt sorry for the cats, of course, cutting them up like that, but I couldn't help it.

speaker: None
text: This flute is beyond any world's standards of good and evil, love or hatred.

speaker: None
text: Making these flutes has been my longtime calling, and I've always done a decent job of fulfilling my role and doing my bit.

speaker: None
text: Nothing to be ashamed of.

speaker: None
text: I got married, had children, and made more than enough flutes.

speaker: None
text: So I'm not going to make any more.

speaker: None
text: Just between you and me, I'm thinking of taking all the flutes I've made and creating a much larger, far more powerful flute out of them--a super-size flute that becomes a system unto itself.

speaker: None
text: Right now I'm heading to a place where I can construct that kind of flute.

speaker: None
text: I'm not the one who decides whether that flute turns out to be good or evil, and neither are you.

speaker: None
text: It all depends on when and where I am.

speaker: None
text: In that sense I'm a man totally without prejudices, like history or the weather--completely unbiased.

speaker: None
text: And since I am, I can transform into a kind of system.

speaker: None
text: He removed his silk hat, rubbed the thinning hair on top of his head, put the hat back on, and quickly adjusted the brim.

speaker: None
text: Once I play this flute, getting rid of you will be a snap.

speaker: None
text: The thing is, I don't feel like playing it right now.

speaker: None
text: It takes a lot out of me, and I don't want to waste any strength.

speaker: None
text: I'll need all of it later on.

speaker: None
text: But whether I play the flute or not, you can't stop me.

speaker: None
text: That should be obvious.

speaker: None
text: The man cleared his throat once more, and rubbed the slight swell of his belly.

speaker: None
text: Do you know what limbo is?

speaker: None
text: It's the neutral point between life and death.

speaker: None
text: A kind of sad, gloomy place.

speaker: None
text: Where I am now, in other words--this forest.

speaker: None
text: I died, at my own bidding, but haven't gone on to the next world.

speaker: None
text: I'm a soul in transition, and a soul in transition is formless.

speaker: None
text: I've merely adopted this form for the time being.

speaker: None
text: That's why you can't hurt me.

speaker: None
text: You follow me?

speaker: None
text: Even if I were to bleed all over the place, it's not real blood.

speaker: None
text: Even if I were to suffer horribly, it's not real suffering.

speaker: None
text: The only one who could wipe me out right now is someone who's qualified to do so.

speaker: None
text: And--sad to say--you don't fit the bill.

speaker: None
text: You're nothing more than an immature, mediocre illusion.

speaker: None
text: No matter how determined you may be, eliminating me's impossible for the likes of you.

speaker: None
text: The man looked at the boy named Crow and beamed.

speaker: None
text: How 'bout it?

speaker: None
text: Want to give it a try?

speaker: None
text: As if that was the signal he'd been waiting for, the boy named Crow spread his wings wide, leaped off the branch, and darted straight at him.

speaker: None
text: He seized the man's chest with both talons, drew his head back, and brought his beak down on the man's right eye, pecking away fiendishly like he was hacking away with a pickax, his jet black wings flapping noisily all the while.

speaker: None
text: The man put up no resistance, didn't lift a finger to protect himself.

speaker: None
text: He didn't cry out, either.

speaker: None
text: Instead, he laughed out loud.

speaker: None
text: His hat fell to the ground, and his eyeball was soon shredded and hanging from its socket.

speaker: None
text: The boy named Crow tenaciously attacked the other eye now.

speaker: None
text: Once both eyes were replaced by vacant cavities, he turned immediately to the man's face, pecking away, slashing it all over.

speaker: None
text: His face was soon cut to ribbons, pieces of skin flying off, blood spurting out, nothing more than a lump of reddish flesh.

speaker: None
text: Crow next attacked the top of his head, where the hair was thinnest, and still the man kept on laughing.

speaker: None
text: The more vicious the attack became, the louder he laughed, as if the whole situation was so hilarious he couldn't control himself.

speaker: None
text: The man never took his eyes--now vacant sockets--off Crow, and in between laughs managed to choke out a few words.

speaker: None
text: See, what'd I tell you?

speaker: None
text: Don't make me laugh.

speaker: None
text: You can try all you want, but it's not going to hurt me.

speaker: None
text: You're not qualified to do that.

speaker: None
text: You're just a flimsy illusion, a cheap echo.

speaker: None
text: It's useless, no matter what you do.

speaker: None
text: Don't you get it?

speaker: None
text: The boy named Crow stabbed at the mouth these words had come from.

speaker: None
text: His huge wings ceaselessly beat at the air, a few shiny black feathers coming loose, swirling in the air like fragments of a soul.

speaker: None
text: Crow tore at the man's tongue, grabbed it with his beak, and yanked with all his might.

speaker: None
text: It was long and hugely thick, and once it was pulled out from deep within the man's throat, it squirmed like a gigantic mollusk, forming dark words.

speaker: None
text: Without a tongue, however, not even this man could laugh anymore.

speaker: None
text: He looked like he couldn't breathe, either, but still he held his sides and shook with soundless laughter.

speaker: None
text: The boy named Crow listened, and this unheard laughter--as vacant and ominous as wind blowing over a far-off desert--never ceased.

speaker: None
text: It sounded, in fact, very much like an otherworldly flute.

speaker: None
text: 47 I wake up just after dawn, boil water on the electric hot plate, and make some tea.

speaker: None
text: I sit down beside the window to see what, if anything, is going on outside.

speaker: None
text: Everything is dead quiet, with no sign of anybody on the street.

speaker: None
text: Even the birds seem reluctant to launch into their usual morning chorus.

speaker: None
text: The hills to the east are barely edged in a faint light.

speaker: None
text: The place is surrounded by high hills, which explains why dawn comes so late and twilight so early.

speaker: None
text: I go over to the nightstand where my watch is to check the time, but the digital screen's a complete blank.

speaker: None
text: When I push a few buttons at random, nothing happens.

speaker: None
text: The batteries should still be good, but for some unfathomable reason the thing stopped while I was sleeping.

speaker: None
text: I put the watch back on top of my pillow and rub my left wrist, where I normally wear it, with my right.

speaker: None
text: Not that time's much of a factor here.

speaker: None
text: As I gaze at the vacant, birdless scene outside, I suddenly want to read a book-- any book.

speaker: None
text: As long as it's shaped like a book and has printing, it's fine by me.

speaker: None
text: I just want to hold a book in my hands, turn the pages, scan the words with my eyes.

speaker: None
text: Only one problem--there isn't a book in sight.

speaker: None
text: In fact, it's like printing hasn't been invented here.

speaker: None
text: I quickly look around the room, and sure enough, there's nothing at all with any writing on it.

speaker: None
text: I open the chest of drawers in the bedroom to see what kind of clothes are inside.

speaker: None
text: Everything's neatly folded.

speaker: None
text: None of the clothes are new.

speaker: None
text: The colors are faded, the material soft from countless washings.

speaker: None
text: Still, they look clean.

speaker: None
text: There's round-neck shirts, underwear, socks, cotton shirts with collars, and cotton trousers.

speaker: None
text: Not a perfect fit, but pretty much my size.

speaker: None
text: All the clothes are perfectly plain and design-free, like the whole idea of clothes with patterns never existed.

speaker: None
text: None of them have any makers' labels--so much for any writing there.

speaker: None
text: I exchange my smelly T-shirt for a gray one from the drawer that smells like sunlight and soap.

speaker: None
text: A while later--how much later I couldn't say--the girl arrives.

speaker: None
text: She taps lightly on the door and, without waiting for an answer, opens it.

speaker: None
text: The door doesn't have any kind of lock.

speaker: None
text: Her canvas bag is slung over her shoulder.

speaker: None
text: The sky behind her is already light.

speaker: None
text: She goes straight to the kitchen and cooks some eggs in a small black frying pan.

speaker: None
text: There's a pleasant sizzle as the eggs hit the hot oil, and the fresh cooking smells waft through the room.

speaker: None
text: Meanwhile, she toasts some bread in a squat little toaster that looks like a prop from an old movie.

speaker: None
text: Her clothes and hair are the same as the night before--a light blue dress, hair pinned back.

speaker: None
text: Her skin is so smooth and beautiful, and her slim, porcelain-like arms glisten in the morning sun.

speaker: None
text: Through the open window a tiny bee buzzes in, as if to make the world a little more complete.

speaker: None
text: The girl carries the food over to the table, sits in a chair, and watches me eat the vegetable omelette and buttered toast and drink some herb tea.

speaker: None
text: She doesn't eat or drink anything.

speaker: None
text: The whole thing's a repeat of last night.

speaker: None
text: Don't people here cook their own meals?

speaker: None
text: I ask her.

speaker: None

text: As I mentioned before, I think this was all predestined, Oshima says.

speaker: None
text: I knew it, and so did she.

speaker: None
text: Though when it actually happens, of course, it's pretty hard to take.

speaker: None
text: When he pauses, I feel like I should say something, but the words won't come.

speaker: Oshima
text: According to her wishes, there won't be a funeral, Oshima continues.

speaker: None
text: She was quietly cremated.

speaker: None
text: She left a will in a drawer in her desk upstairs.

speaker: None
text: She left her entire estate to the foundation that runs the library.

speaker: None
text: She left me her Mont Blanc pen as a keepsake.

speaker: None
text: And a painting for you.

speaker: None
text: The one of the boy on the shore.

speaker: None
text: You'll take it, won't you?

speaker: None
text: I nod.

speaker: None
text: It's all wrapped up over there, ready to go.

speaker: None
text: Thanks," I say, finally able to speak.

speaker: Oshima
text: Tell me something, Kafka Tamura, Oshima says.

speaker: None
text: He picks up a pencil and gives it his usual twirl.

speaker: None
text: Is it okay if I ask you a question?

speaker: None
text: I nod.

speaker: None
text: I didn't need to tell you she died, did I?

speaker: None
text: You already knew.

speaker: None
text: Again I nod.

speaker: None
text: I think I did.

speaker: Oshima
text: I thought so," Oshima says, and draws a deep breath.

speaker: None
text: Would you like some water or something?

speaker: None
text: To tell you the truth, you look as parched as a desert.

speaker: None
text: Thanks, I could use some.

speaker: None
text: I am pretty thirsty, but hadn't realized it until he mentioned it.

speaker: None
text: I down the ice water he brings me in a single gulp, so fast my head starts to ache.

speaker: None
text: I put the empty glass back on the table.

speaker: None
text: Care for some more?

speaker: None
text: I shake my head.

speaker: None
text: What are your plans now?

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima asks.

speaker: None
text: I'm going to go back to Tokyo, I reply.

speaker: None
text: What are you going to do there?

speaker: None
text: Go to the police, first of all, and tell them what I know.

speaker: None
text: If I don't, they'll be after me the rest of my life.

speaker: None
text: And then I'll most likely go back to school.

speaker: None
text: Not that I want to, but I have to at least finish junior high.

speaker: None
text: If I just put up with it for a few months and graduate, then I can do whatever I want.

speaker: Oshima
text: Makes sense," Oshima says.

speaker: None
text: He narrows his eyes and looks at me.

speaker: None
text: That sounds like the best plan.

speaker: None
text: More and more I've been thinking that's the way to go.

speaker: None
text: You can run but you can't hide?

speaker: None
text: Yeah, I guess so," I say.

speaker: None
text: You've grown up.

speaker: None
text: I shake my head.

speaker: None
text: I can't say a thing.

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima lightly taps the eraser end of a pencil against his temple a couple of times.

speaker: None
text: The phone rings, but he ignores it.

speaker: None
text: Every one of us is losing something precious to us, he says after the phone stops ringing.

speaker: None
text: Lost opportunities, lost possibilities, feelings we can never get back again.

speaker: None
text: That's part of what it means to be alive.

speaker: None
text: But inside our heads--at least that's where I imagine it--there's a little room where we store those memories.

speaker: None
text: A room like the stacks in this library.

speaker: None
text: And to understand the workings of our own heart we have to keep on making new reference cards.

speaker: None
text: We have to dust things off every once in a while, let in fresh air, change the water in the flower vases.

speaker: None
text: In other words, you'll live forever in your own private library.

speaker: None
text: I stare at the pencil in his hand.

speaker: None
text: It pains me to look at it, but I have to be the world's toughest fifteen-year-old, at least for a while longer.

speaker: None
text: Or pretend to be.

speaker: None
text: I take a deep breath, fill my lungs with air, and manage to inhale that lump of emotion.

speaker: None
text: Is it all right if I come back here someday?

speaker: None
text: I ask.

speaker: Oshima
text: Of course, Oshima says, and lays his pencil back on the counter.

speaker: None
text: He links his hands behind his head and looks straight at me.

speaker: None
text: The word is that I'll be in charge of the library for a while.

speaker: None
text: And I imagine I'll need an assistant.

speaker: None
text: Once you're free of the police, school, what have you--and provided you want to, of course--I'd love to have you back.

speaker: None
text: The town and I aren't going anywhere, not for the time being.

speaker: None
text: People need a place they can belong.

speaker: None
text: Thanks," I tell him.

speaker: None
text: You're quite welcome, he says.

speaker: None
text: Your brother said he'd teach me how to surf.

speaker: None
text: That's great.

speaker: None
text: He doesn't take to most people," he says.

speaker: None
text: He's a bit of a difficult person.

speaker: None
text: I nod, and smile.

speaker: None
text: They really are quite alike, these two brothers.

speaker: Oshima
text: Kafka, Oshima says, looking deep into my eyes.

speaker: None
text: I could be wrong, but I think that's the first time I've ever seen you smile.

speaker: None
text: You could be right," I say.

speaker: None
text: I most definitely am smiling.

speaker: None
text: And blushing.

speaker: None
text: When are you going back to Tokyo?

speaker: None
text: Right now, I think.

speaker: None
text: Can't you wait till evening?

speaker: None
text: I can drive you to the station after we close up.

speaker: None
text: I consider this, then shake my head.

speaker: None
text: Thanks.

speaker: None
text: But I think it's best if I leave right away.

speaker: Oshima
text: Oshima nods.

speaker: None
text: He goes into a back room and brings out the neatly wrapped painting.

speaker: Kafka Tamura
text: He also puts a single copy of the record "Kafka on the Shore" in a bag and hands it to me.

speaker: None
text: A little present from me.

speaker: None
text: Thanks," I say.

speaker: Miss Saeki
text: Is it okay if I go up and see Miss Saeki's room one more time?

speaker: None
text: Go right ahead.

speaker: None
text: Would you come with me?

speaker: None
text: Of course.

speaker: None
text: We go upstairs to her room.

speaker: None
text: I stand in front of her desk, lightly touch its surface, and think over all the things it has absorbed.

speaker: None
text: I picture her slumped facedown on the desk.

speaker: None
text: How she always sat there, the window behind her, busily writing away.

speaker: None
text: How I brought her coffee, when she'd glance up as I opened the door and came inside.

speaker: None
text: How she always smiled at me.

speaker: None
text: What was it she was writing here?

speaker: None
text: I ask.

speaker: Oshima
text: I don't know, Oshima replies.

speaker: None
text: One thing I do know for sure is she took a lot of secrets with her when she left this world.

speaker: None
text: A lot of theories as well, I silently think.

speaker: None
text: The window's open, the June breeze gently rustling the hem of the white lace curtains.

speaker: None
text: A faint scent of the sea is in the air.

speaker: None
text: I remember feeling the sand in my hand at the beach.

speaker: Oshima
text: I walk away from the desk and over to Oshima, and hold him tight.

speaker: None
text: His slim body calls up all sorts of nostalgic memories.

speaker: None
text: He gently rubs my hair.

speaker: Kafka Tamura
text: The world is a metaphor, Kafka Tamura, he says into my ear.

speaker: None
text: But for you and me this library alone is no metaphor.

speaker: None
text: It's always just this library.

speaker: None
text: I want to make sure we understand that.

speaker: None
text: Of course," I say.

speaker: None
text: It's a unique, special library.

speaker: None
text: And nothing else can ever take its place.

speaker: None
text: I nod.

speaker: Oshima
text: Good-bye, Kafka, Oshima says.

speaker: Oshima
text: Good-bye, Oshima, I say.

speaker: None
text: You know, you look good in that necktie.

speaker: None
text: He lets go of me, looks me in the face, and smiles.

speaker: None
text: I've been waiting for you to say that.

speaker: None
text: Shouldering my backpack, I walk to the local station and take the train back to Takamatsu Station.

speaker: None
text: I buy a ticket to Tokyo at the counter.

speaker: None
text: The train will get in to Tokyo late at night, so the first thing I'll have to do is find a place to stay for the night, then head over to my house in Nogata the next day.

speaker: None
text: I'll be all alone in that huge, vacant house.

speaker: None
text: Nobody's waiting for me to come home.

speaker: None
text: But I have no other place to go back to.

speaker: Sakura
text: I use a public phone at the station and call Sakura's cell phone.

speaker: None
text: She's in the middle of work but says she can spare a couple minutes.

speaker: None
text: That's fine, I tell her.

speaker: None
text: I'm going back to Tokyo now, I tell her.

speaker: None
text: I'm at Takamatsu Station.

speaker: None
text: I just wanted to tell you.

speaker: None
text: You're finished running away from home?

speaker: None
text: I guess so.

speaker: None
text: Fifteen's a little early to run away, anyway," she says.

speaker: None
text: But what are you going to do back in Tokyo?

speaker: None
text: Go back to school.

speaker: None
text: That's probably a good idea," she says.

speaker: None
text: You're going back to Tokyo too, aren't you?

speaker: None
text: Yeah, probably in September.

speaker: None
text: I might go on a trip somewhere in the summer.

speaker: None
text: Can I see you in Tokyo?

speaker: None
text: Yeah, of course," she says.

speaker: None
text: Can you tell me your number?

speaker: None
text: I give her the number at my house, and she writes it down.

speaker: None
text: I had a dream about you the other day, she says.

speaker: None
text: I had one about you too.

speaker: None
text: A pretty raunchy one, I bet?

speaker: None
text: Could be," I admit.

speaker: None
text: But it was just a dream.

speaker: None
text: What about yours?

speaker: None
text: Mine wasn't raunchy.

speaker: None
text: You were in this huge house that was like a maze, walking around, searching for some special room, but you couldn't find it.

speaker: None
text: There was somebody else in the house, looking for you.

speaker: None
text: I tried to yell a warning, but you couldn't hear me.

speaker: None
text: A pretty scary dream.

speaker: None
text: When I woke up I was exhausted from all that yelling.

speaker: None
text: I've been worried about you ever since.

speaker: None
text: I appreciate it," I say.

speaker: None
text: But that's just a dream too.

speaker: None
text: Nothing bad happened to you?

speaker: None
text: No, nothing bad.

speaker: None
text: No, nothing bad, I tell myself.

speaker: Kafka Tamura
text: Good-bye, Kafka, she says.

speaker: None
text: I have to get back to work, but if you ever want to talk, just call me, okay?

speaker: None
text: Good-bye," I say.

speaker: None
text: Sister, I add.

speaker: None
text: Over the bridge and across the water we go, and I transfer to the bullet train at Okayama Station.

speaker: None
text: I sink back in my seat and close my eyes.

speaker: None
text: My body gradually adjusts to the train's vibration.

speaker: Kafka Tamura
text: The tightly wrapped painting of Kafka on the Shore is at my feet.

speaker: None
text: I can feel it there.

speaker: Miss Saeki
text: I want you to remember me, Miss Saeki says, and looks right into my eyes.

speaker: None
text: If you remember me, then I don't care if everyone else forgets.

speaker: None
text: Time weighs down on you like an old, ambiguous dream.

speaker: None
text: You keep on moving, trying to slip through it.

speaker: None
text: But even if you go to the ends of the earth, you won't be able to escape it.

speaker: None
text: Still, you have to go there--to the edge of the world.

speaker: None
text: There's something you can't do unless you get there.

speaker: None
text: It starts to rain just after we pass Nagoya.

speaker: None
text: I stare at the drops streaking the dark window.

speaker: None
text: It was raining the day I left Tokyo, too.

speaker: None
text: I picture rain falling in all sorts of places--in a forest, on the sea, a highway, a library.

speaker: None
text: Rain falling at the edge of the world.

speaker: None
text: I close my eyes and relax, letting my tense muscles go loose.

speaker: None
text: I listen to the steady hum of the train.

speaker: None
text: And then, without warning, a warm tear spills from my eye, runs down my cheek to my mouth, and, after a while, dries up.

speaker: None
text: No matter, I tell myself.

speaker: None
text: It's just one tear.

speaker: None
text: It doesn't even feel like it's mine, more like part of the rain outside.

speaker: None
text: Did I do the right thing?

speaker: None
text: You did the right thing, the boy named Crow says.

speaker: None
text: You did what was best.

speaker: None
text: No one else could have done as well as you did.

speaker: None
text: After all, you're the genuine article: the toughest fifteen-year-old in the world.

speaker: None
text: But I still don't know anything about life," I protest.

speaker: None
text: Look at the painting, he says.

speaker: None
text: And listen to the wind.

speaker: None
text: I nod.

speaker: None
text: I know you can do it.

speaker: None
text: I nod again.

speaker: None
text: You'd better get some sleep, the boy named Crow says.

speaker: None
text: When you wake up, you'll be part of a brand-new world.

speaker: None
text: You finally fall asleep.

speaker: None
text: And when you wake up, it's true.
You are part of a brand-new world.
